The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: THE Feign'd Curtizans, OR, A Nights Intrigue.
As it is Acted at the Dukes Theatre.
LONDON, Printed for Jacob Tonson at the Judges Head in Chancery-Lane near Fleet-street. 1679.

div.head: TO Mrs. ELLENGUIN.
div.p:
TIS no wonder that hitherto I followed not the good example of the believing Poets, since less faith and zeal then you alone can inspire, had wanted power to have reduc't me to the true worship: Your permission, Madam, has inlightened me, and I with shame look back on my past Ignorance, which suffered me not to pay an Adoration long since, where there was so very much due, yet even now though secure in my opinion, I make this Sacrisice with infinite fear and trembling, well knowing that so Excellent and perfect a Creature as your self differs only from the Divine powers in this; the Offerings made to you ought to be worthy of you, whilst they accept the will alone; and how Madam, would your Altars be loaded, if like heaven you gave permission to all that had a will and desire to approach 'em, who now at distance can only wish and admire, which all mankinde agree to do; as if Madam, you alone had the pattent from heaven to ingross all hearts; and even those distant slaves whom you conquer with your fame, pay an equall tribute to those that have the blessing of being wounded by your Eyes, and boast the happiness of beholding
you dayly; insomuch that succeeding ages who shall with joy survey your History shall Envy us who lived in this, and saw those charming wonders which they can only reade of, and whom we ought in charity to pity, since all the Pictures, pens or pencills can draw, will give give 'em but a faint Idea of what we h • ve the honour to see in such absolute Perfection, they can only guess She was infinitely fair, witty, and deserving, but to what Vast degrees in all, they can only Judge who liv'd to Gaze and Listen; for besides Madam, all the Charms and attractions and powers of your Sex, you have Beauties peculiar to your self, an eternal sweetness, youth and ayr, which never dwelt in any face but yours, of which not one unimitable Grace could be ever borrow'd, or assumed, though with never so much industry, to adorn another, they cannot steal a look or smile from you to inhance their own beauties price, but all the world will know it yours; so Natural and so fitted are all your Charms and Excellencies to one another, so intirely design'd and created to make up in you alone the most perfect lovely thing in the world; you never appear but you glad the hearts of all that have the happy fortune to see you, as if you were made on purpose to put the whole world into good Humour, whenever you look abroad, and when you speak, men crowd to listen with that awfull reverence as to Holy Oracles or Divine Prophesies, and bears away the precious words to tell at home to all the attentive family, the Gracefull things you utter'd and cry, but oh she
spoke with such an Ayr, so gay, that half the beauty's lost in the repetition. 'Tis this that ought to make your Sex vain enough to despise the malicious world that will •… llow a woman no wit, and bless our selves for living in an Age that can produce so wondrous an argument as your undeniable self, to sh •… me those boasting talkers who are Judges of nothing but faults.

But how much in vain Madam, I endeavour to tell you the sence of all mankinde with mine, since to the utmost Limits of the Universe your mighty. Conquests are made known: And who can doubt the Power of that Illustrious Beauty, the Charms of that tongue, and the greatness of that minde, who has subdu'd the most powerfull and Glorious Monarch of the world: And so well you bear the honours your were born for, with a greatness so unaffected, an affabillity so easie, an Humor so soft, so far from Pride or Vanity, that the most Envious & most disaffected can finde no cause or reason to wish you less, Nor can Heaven give you more, who has exprest a particular care of you every way, and above all in bestowing on the world and you, two noble Branches, who have all the greatness and sweetness of their Royal and beautiful stock; and who give us too a hopeful Prospect of what their future Braveries will perform, when they shall shoot up and spread themselves to that degree, that all the lesser world may finde repose beneath their shades; and whom you have permitted to wear those glorious Titles which you your self Generously neglected, well
knowing with the noble Poet; 'tis better far to merit Titles then to wear 'em.

Can you then blame my Ambition, Madam, that lays this at your feet, and begs a Sanctuary where all pay so great a Veneration? 'twas Dedicated yours before it had a being, and overbusy to render it worthy of the Honour, made it less grateful; and Poetry like Lovers often fares the worse by taking, too much pains to please; but under so Gracious an Influence my tender Lawrells may thrive, till they become fit Wreaths to offer to the Rays that improve their Growth: which Madam, I humbly implore, you still permit her ever to do, who is,

closer.signed: Your most humble; and Most Obedient Servant. A. Behn.

div.head: The PROLOGUE,
div.l: THe devil take this cursed plotting Age,
'T has ruin'd all our Plots upon the Stage;
Suspicions, New Elections, Jealousies,
Fresh Informations, New discoveries,
Do so employ the busie fearful Town,
Our honest calling here is useless grown;
Each fool turns Politician now, and wears
A formal face, and talks of State-affairs;
Makes Acts, Decrees, and a new Modell draws
For regulation both of Church and Laws;
Tires out his empty noddle to invent
What rule and method's best in government;
But Wit as if 'twere Jesuiticall,
Is an abomination to ye all:
To what a wretched pass will poor Plays come,
This must be damn'd, the Plot is laid in Rome
'Tis hard—yet—
Not one amongst ye all I'le undertake,
Ere thought that we should suffer for Religions sake:
Who wou'd have thought that wou'd have been th'occasion,
Of any contest in our hopefull Nation?
For my own principles, faith, let me tell yo •…
I'me still of the Religion of my Cully,
And till these dangerous times they'd none to fix on,
But now are something in meer contradiction,
And piously pretend, these are not days,
For keeping Mistresses and seeing Plays.
Who says this Age a Reformation wants,
When Betty Currer's Lovers all turn Saints?
In vain alas I flatter, swear, and vow,
You'l scarce do any thing for Charity now:
Yet I am handsome still, still young and mad,
Can w •… eadle, lie, dissemble, jilt—egad,
As well and artfully as •… rd I did,
Yet not one Conquest can I gain or hope,
No Prentice, not a Foreman of a Shop,
So that I want extremely New Supplies;
Of my last. Coxcomb, faith, these were the Prize;
And by the tatter'd Ensignes you may know,
These spoils were of a Victory long ago:
Who wou'd have thought such hellish times to've seen,
When I shou'd be neglected at eighteen?
That Youth and Beauty shou'd be quite undone,
A Pox upon the Whore of Babylon.

row.cell: An Old Count Uncle to Julio.
His Nephew, a young Count, contracted to Laura Lucretia.
A young Count contracted to Marcella, deform'd, revengeful.
Suppos'd Pimp to the two Curtezans.
A young Lady of Quallity, contracted to Julio, in love with Galliard, and Sister to Octavio.
Sisters to Julio, and Nieces to Morisini, pass for Curtizans by the Names of Euphemia & Silvianetta

div.head: THE Feign'dCurtizans, OR, A NIGHTS INTRIGUE.

sp.stage: Enter Laura, Lucretia, and Silvio richly drest; Antonio attending, Coming all in in haste.

sp.speaker: Silvio.
sp.p: MAdam, you need not make such haste away, the Stranger that follow'd us from St. Peters Church, pursues us no longer, and we have now lost sight of him: Lord who wou'd have thought the approach of a handsome Cavalier should have possest Dona Laura Lucretia with fear?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I do not fear my Silvio, but I wou'd have this new Habitation which I've design'd for love, known to none but him to whom I've destin'd my heatt:—ah wou'd he know the Conquest he has made, [Aside.] Nor went I this evening to Church with any other Devotion, but that which warms my heart for my young English Cavalier, whom I hop't to have seen there, and I must finde some way to let him know my passion which is too high for souls like mine to hide.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Madam, the Cavalier's in view again, and hot in the pursuit

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lets haste away then, and Silvio do you lag behinde, 'twill give him an opportunity of Enquiring, whilst I get out of sight,—be sure you conceal my Name and Quality, and tell him—any thing but truth—tell him I am La Silvianetta the young Roman Curtizan, or what you please to hide me from his knowledge.
sp.stage: Enter Julio and Page in Pursuit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Boy fall you into discourse with that Page, and learn his Ladys Name—whilst I pursue her farther.
sp.stage: Page salutes Silvio, who returns it, they go out as talking to each other.
Enter Sr Harry Fillamour and Galliard.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: He follows her close, whoe're they be: I see this trade of Love goes forward still.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And will whilst there's difference in Sexes. But Harry the women, the delicate Women I was speaking of?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Prethee tell me no more of thy fine Women, Frank, thou hast not been in Rome above a Month, and thou'ast been a Dozen times in Love as thou call'st it: to me there is no pleasure like Constancie.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Constancy! and woudst thou have me one of those dull Lovers who believe it their Duty to Love a Woman till her Hair and Eyes change Colour for fear of the Scandalous Name of an inconstant! No, my Passion like great Victors hates the lazy stay, but having vanquisht, prepares for new Conquests.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Which you gain as they do Towns by Fire, lose'em even in the taking, thou wo't grow Penitent and weary of these Dangerous sollys.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: But I am yet two young for both: Let old Age and infirmity bring Repentance,—there's her f •… eble Province, and even then too we finde no Plague like being depriv'd of dear Woman-kinde.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I hate Playing about a Flame that will consume me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Away with your Antiquated Notions, and let's once hear sence from thee: Examine but the whole World Harry, and thou wilt sinde a Beautifull woman the desire of the Noblest, and the reward of the Bravest.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: And the common Prize of Coxcombs: times are alter'd now, Frank, why else shou'd the Virtuous be cornuted, the Coward be carest, the Villain role with Six, and the Fool lye with her Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Meer Accident Sir: and the kindness of Fortune, but a Pretty witty young Creature, such as this Silvianetta, and Euphemia, is certainly the greatest blessing this wicked World can afford us.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I believe the Lawful enjoyment of such a Woman, and honest too, wou'd be a blessing.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Lawful enjoyment! Prethee what's lawful enjoyment, but to enioy'em according to the generous indulgent Law of Nature; enjoy'em as we do Meat, Drink, Ayr and Light, and all the rest of her common blessings;—therefore prithee dear Knight, let me govern thee but for a day, and I will shew thee such a Signiora, such a Beauty, another manner of piece then your so admired Vitterboan, Dona Marcella, of whom you boast so much.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: And yet this rare piece is but a Curtizan, in course plain English, a very Whore!—
Who filthily exposes all her Beautys to him can give her most, not Love her best.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Whe faith, to thy comfort be it spoken, she does distribute her char •… s at that easy rate.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p:
O •…
〈◊〉
•… ast distance between an innocent passion, and a poor faithless 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Innocent Passion at Rome! Oh 'tis not to be nam'd but in some Northern Climat: to be an Anchoret here, is to be an Epicure in Greenland; impossibillities Harry!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Sure •… ou hast been advising with Sir Signal Buffoons Governor! that formall! piece of nonsense and Hipocrifie.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: No faith, I brought the Humour along with me to Rome, and for your Governor I have not seen him yet, though he lodge in this same House with us, and you promis'd to bring me acquainted with long since.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I'le do't this very minute!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: No, I'me oblig'd not to engage my self this Evening, 〈◊〉 I expect the arrival of Count Julio, whose last Letters assur'd me wou'd be to night.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Julio! What the young Itallian Count you made me acquainted with last Summer in England?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: The same, the Ambasadors Nephew, a good youth and on •… I esteem.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I hope my Page will bring intelligence who this beauty is.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Hah, Julio! Welcome dear Friend.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir Harry Fillamour! how glad am I to meet you in a Country where I have power to repay you all those Friendships I receiv'd when I was a stranger to yours.
Monsieur Galliard too, nay then I'me sure to want no diversion whilst I stay in Rome.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: But pray, what made you leave England so soon?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: E'ne the great business of Mankinde, Matrimony, I have an Uncle here who has provided me Fetters which I must put on, he says, they will be easy, I lik't the Character of my Mistress well enough, a brave Masculine Lady, a Roman of Quality, Dona Laura Lucretia, till as luck wou'd have it at my arrival this Evening, stepping into S. Peters Church, I saw a woman there that fir'd my heart, and whom I follow'd to her house; but meeting none that cou'd inform me who she was, I left my Page to make the discovery, whilst I with equal impatience came to look out you; whose sight I prefer even to a new Amour, resolving not to visit home, to which I have been a stranger this seven years, till I had kist your hands, and gain'd your promise to accompany me to Vitterbo.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Vitterbo! is that your place of Residence?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes; 'tis a pretty Town, and many noble Familys inhabit there, stor'd too with Beauties, at least, 'twas wont to be: have you not seen it?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes! and a Beauty there too lately for his repose, who has made him sigh and look so like an Ass ever since he came to Rome.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'me glad you have so powerfull an argument to invite you back, I know she must be rare, and of quality that cou'd engage your heart.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: She's both, it most unluckily fell out, that I was recommended by a Person of Quality in England to a Nobleman at Vitterbo, who being a man of a temper frank and gallant, receiv'd me with less Ceremony then is usual in Italy. I had the freedom of the House, one of the finest Villa's belonging to Vitterbo, and the pleasure to see and converse at a distance, with one of the loveliest persons in the World, a Neece of this old Counts.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Very well, and cou'd you see her but at distance, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Oh, no, 'twas all I durst desire, or she durst give; I came too late to hope; she being before promis'd in Marriage to a more happy man, the Consummation of which waits only the arival of a Brother of hers, who is now at the Court of France, and every day expected.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah! Signior Petro:

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Come Sir, we'l take a turn in the i'th gallery, for this pimp never appears but Frances desires to be in private.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Thou wrong'st an honest ingenious fellow to call him pimp.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah Signior, what his worship pleases!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: That thou art I'le be sworn, or what any mans worship pleases, for let me tell ye Harry, he is capacitated to oblige in any quality; for Sir, he's your brokering Jew, your Fencing, Dancing and Civillity-Master, your Linguist, your Antiquary, your Bravo, your Pathick, your Whore, your Pimp, and a thousand more Excellencies he has to supply the necessities of the wanting stranger.—Well sirrah—What designe now upon Sir Signal and his wise Governor;—What do you represent now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Barber Sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And why a Barber, good Signior Petro?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh Sir, the sooner to take the heights of their judgments, it gives handsome opportunities to commend their faces, for if they are pleased with flattery, the certain sign of a fool's to be most tickled when most commended, I conclude 'em the fitter for my purpose; they already put great confidence in me, will have no Masters but of my recommending, all which I supply my self, by the help of my several disguises; by which and my industry, I doubt not but to pick up a good honest painfull livelihood, by cheating these two Reverend Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How the Devil got'st thou this credit with 'em?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh easily Sir, as knaves get estates, or fools employments.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I hope amongst all your good qualities you forgot not your more natural one of pimping.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No, I assure you Sir, I have told Sir Signal Buffoon; that no Man lives here without his Inamorata, which very word has so fir'd him, that he's resolv'd to have an Inamorata, whatever it cost him, and as in all things else I have in that too promis'd my assistance.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: If you assist him no better then you have done me he may stay long enough for his Inamorato.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why faith Sir, I lye at my young Lady night and day, but she is so loath to part with that same Maiden-head of hers yet—but to morrow night Sir ther's hopes.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To morrow night! Oh 'tis an Age in Love! desire knows no time but the present, 'tis now I wish, and now I wou'd enjoy, a new day ought to bring a new desire.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Alas Sir I'me but an humble Bravo.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes thou'rt a pimp, yet want'st the art to procure a longing lover the woman he adores, tho' but a common Curtizan—Oh confound her Maidenhead—She understands her trade too well to have that badge of Innocence.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I offered her her price Sir—.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Double it, give any thing, for that's the best receipt I ever found to soften womens hearts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well Sir, she will be this Evening in the Garden of Medices Villa, there you may get an opportunity to advance your interest—I must step and trim Mr. Tickletext, and then am at your service!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What is this Knight and his Governor who have the blessed fortune to be manag'd by this Squire?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Certain fools Galliard makes use on when he has a minde to laugh: and whom I never thought worth a visit since I came to Rome: and he's like to profit much by his Travells, who keeps company with all the English, especially the Fops.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I came not abroad to return with the formallity of a Judge; and these are such anditotes against Melancholy as wou'd make thee fond of fooling.—Our Knights Father is even the first Gentleman of his House, a fellow, who having the good Fortune to be much a fool and knave, had the attendant blessing of getting an Estate of some eight thousand a year, with this Coxcomb to inherit it; who (to agrandize the Name and Family of the Buffoons) was made a Knight, but to refine throughout and make a compleat Fop, was sent abroad under the Government of one Mr. Tickletext his zealous Fathers Chaplain, as errant a block-head as a man wou'd wish to hear Preach: the Father wisely foreseeing the eminent danger that young Travellers are in of being perverted to Popery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Twas well consider'd.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
But for the young Spark there is no description can reach him; 'tis only to be done by himself; let it suffice 'tis a pert, sawcy, conceited
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
Animal, whom you shall just now go see, and admire, for he lodges in the house with us.

sp.speaker: Jnl.
sp.p: With all my heart, I never long'd more for a new acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: And in all probability shall sooner desire to be rid on't. aloone.—

sp.stage: Draws off, and discovers Mr. Tickletext a Trimming, his hair under a Cap, a cloath before him, and Petro Snaps his fingers, takes away the Bason, and goes to wiping his face.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah che Bella! Bella! I swear by these sparkling Eyes, and these soft Plump dimpl'd cheeks, there's not a Signiora in all Rome, cou'd she behold 'em, were able to stand their Temptations, and for La Silvianetta, my life on't she's your own.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Teze, teze, speak softly!—but honest Barberacho, do I, do I indeed look plump, and young, and fresh and—hah!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ay Sir, as the Rosie Morn, young, as old Time in his Infancie, and plump as the Pale-fac't Moon.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: He—Whe this Travelling must needs improve a Man,—Whe how admirably well spoken your very Barbers are here,— [Aside.]—but Barberacho, did the young Gentlewoman say she lik't me? did she Rogue? did she?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A doated on you Signior, doated on you.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Whe, and that's strange now, in the Autumn of my Age too, when Nature began to be impertinent, as a man may say, that a young Lady shou'd fall in love with me——— [Aside.——Whe Barberacho, I do not conceive any great matter of Sin only in visiting a Lady that loves a man, hah.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sin Sir, 'tis a frequent thing now adays in Persons of your Complexion.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Especially here at Rome too, where 'tis no Scandal.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ay Signior, where the Ladys are Priviledg'd, and Fornication Licenc't.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Right! and when 'tis Licens'd 'tis Lawful, and when 'tis Lawful it can be no Sin: besides Barberacho, I may chance to turn her, who knows!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Turn her Signior, Alass any way, which way you please.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: He he he! There thou wert knavish, I doubt—but I mean Convert her—Nothing else I profess Barberacho.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: True Signior, true, she's a Lady of an easy Nature, and an Indifferent Argument well handled will do't—ha— [combing out his Hair. here's your head of Hair—here's your Natural Frize! And such an Ayr it gives the Face!—So Signior—Now you have the utmost my Art can do.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Well Signior:—and where's your looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: My looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Yes Signior your Looking-glass! an English Barber wou'd as soon have forgotten to have snapt his fingers, made his leg, or taken his Money, as have neglected his looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Aye Signior, in your Countrey the Laiety have so little honesty, they are not to be trusted with the taking off your Beard unless you see't done,—but heres a Glass, Sir,
sp.stage: [Tick. Sets himself and smirks in the Glass, Pet. standing behinde him, making horns and grimaces, which Tick. sees in the Glass, gravely rises, turns towards Petro.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Whe how now, Barberacho, what Monstrous faces are you making there?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah my Belly, my Belly, Signior: ah, this Wind-Collick! this Hypocondriach does so torment me! ah—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Alass poor Knave; certo, I thought thou hadst been somewhat uncivil with me, I profess I did;

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Who I Sir, uncivil?—I abuse my Patrone?—I that have almost made my self a Pimp to serve you?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Teze teze, honest Barberacho! no, no, no, all's well, all's well:—but hark y'—you will be discreet and secret in this business now, and above all things conceal the knowledge of this Gentlewoman from Sir Signall and Mr. Galliard.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: The Rack Signior, the Rack shall not extort it.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hold thy hand—there's somewhat for thee, [gives him money. but shall I Rogue—shall I see her to night?——

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To night Sir, meet me in the Piatza D'hispagnia, about 10 a Clock,—I'le meet you there,—but 'tis sit Signior—that I should provide a Collation,—'tis the Custom here Sir.——

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Well, well, what will it come to,—here's an Angel—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Whe Sir 'twill come to—about—for you wou'd do't hansomely—some twenty Crowns.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How man, twenty Crowns?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ay Signior, thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Twenty Crowns—Whe 'tis a Sum, a Portion, a Revenue.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Alass Signior, 'tis nothing with her,—she'le look it out in an hour,—ah such an Eye! so sparkling, with an Amorous twire—thus Sir—then she'le kiss it out in a moment,—such a Lip, so red, so round, and so plump, so soft, and so—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Why has she, has she, Sirrah—hah—here, here, prethee take Money, here, and make no words on't—go, go your way, go—but to entertain Sir Signall with other matter, pray send his Masters to him; if thou canst help him to Masters, and me to Mistresses, thou shalt be the good Genius of us both: but see where he comes.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hah! Sigmor Illustrissimo Barberacho, let me hugg thee my little Miphistophiloucho—de yee see here, how fine your Brokering Jew has made me, Segnior Rabbi Manaseth—Ben-Nebiton, and so sorth; hah—View me round——

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I profess 'tis as sit as if it had been made for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Made for me—Whe Sir, he swore to me by the old Law, that 'twas never worn but once, and that but by one high-German Prince—I have sorgot forgot his name—for the Devil can never remember these damn'd Hogan-Mogan Titles.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: No matter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, but I shou'd be loth to be in any mans clothes, were he never so high a German-Prince, except I knew his name tho.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sir, I hold his Name unnecessary to be remembred, so long as 'twas a Princely penniworth.—Barberacho get you gone, and send the Masters.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Why how now Governour! how now Signior Tickletext! prethee how cam'st thou so transmograsi'd, ha? whe thou look'st like any new-fledg'd Cupid.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Do I, away you flatter, Do I?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: As I hope to breathe, your face shines through your powder'd hairs like you know what on a barn-door, in a frosty morning.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: What a filthy comparison's there for a man of my coat.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: What, angry—Corpo di me, I meant no harm,—Come, shall's to a Bonar •… ba, where thou shalt part with thy pusilage, and that of thy beard together.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How mean you Sir, a Curtizan, and a Romish Curtizan?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Now my Tuter's up, ha ha ha,—and ever is when one names a whore; be pacifi'd man, be pacifi'd, I know thou hat'st 'em worse then beads or holy-water.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Away you are such another Knight—but leave this Naughty discourse, and prepare for your Fencing and Civility-Masters, who are coming,

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, when Governour, when; oh how I long for my Civility-Master, that I may learn to out-complement all the dull Knights and Squires in Kent, with a Servitore Hulichimo—No signiora Bellissima, base le Mane, de vos signiora scusamia Illustrissimo, caspeto de Bacco, and so I'le run on, hah Governor, hah! won't this be pure?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Notably Ingenious, I profess!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Well I'le send my Staffiera for him incontinente.—he, Jack—a—Cazo, what a Damn'd English name is Jack? let me see—I will call him—Giovanni, which is as much as to say John!—he Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sir, by your favour his English Protestant-Name is John Pepper; and I'le call him by ne're a Popish name in Christiandom.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: I'le call my own man Sir, by what name I please Sir; and let me tell you Reverend Mr. Tickletext, I scorn to be serv'd by any man who's name has not an Acho, or an Oucho, or some Italliano at the end on't—therefore Giovanni Peperacho is the name by which you shall be distinguisht and dignify'd hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sir Signall, Sir Signall, let me tell you, that to call a man out of his name is unwarantable, for Peter is call'd Peter, and John, John, and I'le not see the poor fellow wrong'd of his name for nere a Giovanni in Rome.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Sir I tell you that one Itallian Name is worth any two English names in Europe, and I'le be judg'd by my Civility-Master.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Who shall end the dispute, if he be of my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig
sp.p: Multo vollentiero, which is as much as to say, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: But Sir, my Grandmother wou'd never own me if I should change the cursen name she gave me with her own hands, an't please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: He Bestia! I'le have no more of your Worship, firrah, that old English Sir Reverence, let me have you call me Signior Illustrissimo, or Patrona Mea.—or—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I, that I like well enough now:—but hold, sure this is one of your Masters.
sp.stage: Enter Petro drest like a French Fencing Master.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Signior Barberacho has sent me to teach you de Art of Fencing.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Illustrissimo Signior Monsicur, I am the Person who am to learn.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Stay Sir stay,—let me ask him some few questions first, for Sir I have play'd at Back-Sword and cou'd have handled ye a weapon as well as any man of my time in the University.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Say you so Mr. Tickletext, and I'faith you shall have about with him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hum—hum—Mr. Monsieur—pray what are the Guards that you like best?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Monsieur, eder de Quart or de Terse, dey be both French and Itallian; den for your Parades, degagements, your advancements, your Eloynements, and Retierments: dey be de same;

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Cart and Horse, what new found inventions and words have we here,—Sir I wou'd know, whether you like St. Georges Guard or not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Alon—Monsieur, Mette vous en Guard! take de Flurette.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Nay saith and troth Governor thou shat have a Rubbers with him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Nay certo Sir Signal,—and yet you shall prevail;—well Sir. come your ways?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Set your right foot forward, turn up your hand so—dat be de Quart—Now turn it dus—and dat be de Terse.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hocus, Pocus, Hicksius, Doxius—here be de Cart and here be de Horse—why what's all this for, hah Sir—and where's your guard all this while?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay Sir where's your Guard Sir, as my Governor says, Sir, hah?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, I must instruct you I see—Come your ways Sir.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Tande a Tande non pew,—trust de right hand and de right leg forward together.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I marry Sir, that's a good one indeed! what shall become of my head then Sir, what Guard have I left for that good Mr. Monsieur. hah?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah Morblew, is not dis for every ting?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: No marry is it not Sir, St. Georges Guard is the best for your head whilst you live,——as thus Sir.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Dat Sir, ha ha—dat be Guard for de Back-Sword.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Back-sword Sir, yes, Back-sword, what should it be else.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And dis be de Single-Rapier.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Single-Rapier with a vengeance, there's a weapon for a Gentleman indeed; is all this stir about Single-Rapier?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Single-Rapier! What will you have for de Gentleman, de Cudgell for de Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: No Sir, but I wou'd have it for de Rascally French-man who comes to abuse persons of Quality with Paltry Single-Rapier.—Single Rapier! Come Sir, come,—put your self in your Cart and your Horse as you call it, and I'le shew you the difference.
sp.stage: Undresses himself till he appears in a Ridiculous Posture.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah Monsieur me sall run you two three times through de body, and den you break a me head, what care I for dat:—Pox on his ignorance!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh ho Sir, do your worst Sir, do your worst Sir.
sp.stage: They put themselves into several Guards, and Tick. beats Pet. about the Stage—Enter Gall. Fill. and Jul.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah Monsieur, Monsieur, will you kill a me?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Ah Monsieur where be your Carts now and your Horse, Mr. Monsieur, hah!—and your Single-Rapier Mr. Monsieur hah!—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Why how now Mr. Tickletext, what mortal wars are these? Ajax and Ulisses contending for Achillis his Armour?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: If I be not reveng'd on him, hang me:

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, why who the Devil wou'd have taken my Governor for so tall a man of hands, but Corpo de me Mr. Galliard, I have not seen his Fellow.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Ah Sir, time was, I wou'd have play'd ye a Match at Cudgells with e're a Sophister in the Colledge, but verily I have forgotten it, but here's an impudent French-man that wou'd have past Single-Rapier upon us.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How, nay a my word then he deserv'd to be chastis'd sor't.——but now all's at peace again; Pray know my kinsman, Sir Harry Fillamour.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Yo baco les manos, Signior Illustrissimo Cavaliero,—and yours Signiors who are Multo bien Venito;

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir, you take me Sir—in such a posture Sir—as I protest I have not been seen in this many years.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Exercise is good for health Sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Sir Signal, Yo •… are grown a perfect Itallian? Well Mr. Tickletext you will carry him home a most accomplish't Gentleman I see!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hum, verily Sir though I say it, for a man that never travell'd before, I think I have done reasonably well;—I'le tell you Sir—it was by my directions and advice, that he brought over with him,—two English knives, a thousand of English pins, four pair of Jersey stockings, and as many pair of B •… ck-skin Gloves.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay Sir, for good Gloves you know are very scarce comodities in this Country.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Here Sir at Rome, as you say, above all other places.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Certo meer hedging-Gloves Sir, and the clouterlest seams.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Very right Sir,—and now he talks of Rome,—Pray Sir give me your opinion of the place?—are there not Noble buildings here? rare statues, and admirable Fountains?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Your buildings are pretty buildings, but not comparable to our University-buildings; your Fountains I confess are pretty Springs,—and your statues reasonably well carv'd—but Sir, they are so ancient they are of no vallue! then your Churches are the worst that ever I saw—that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How Sir, the Churches, why I thought Rome had been famous throughout all Europe for fine Churches.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: What think you of St. Peters Church Sir, Is it not a glorious structure?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: St. Peters Church Sir, you may as well call it St. Peters Hall Sir; it has neither Pew, Pullpit, Desk, Steeple, nor Ring of Bells, and call you this a Church Sir? no Sir, I'le say that for little England, and a fig for't, for Churches, easy •… ulpits [Sir Sig. speaks, and sleeping Pews,] they are as well order'd as any Churches in Christiandom: and •… er Rings of Bells Sir, I'am sure were never heard.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Sir there's much in what you say.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: But then Sir, your Rich Altars, and excellent Pictures of the greatest Masters of the World, your delicate Musick, and Voices, make some amends for the other wants.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How Sir! tell me of your Rich Altars, your guegaws and trinkets, and Popish Foperies! with a deal of sing-song—when I say give me Sir five hundred close changes rung by a set of good Ringers, and I'le not exchange 'em for all the Anthens in Europe: and for the Pictures Sir, they are superstition, Idolatrous, and flat Popery.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I'le convince you of that errour that perswades you harmless Pictures are Idolatrous.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How Sir, how Sir, convince me, talk to me of being convinc't and that in favour of Popery; No Sir, by your favour I shall not be convinc't, convinc't quoth a—No Sir far you well an you be for convincing, come away Sir Signall, far you well Sir, far you well—convin'ct.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, so now is my Governor gone in a Fustian-fume, well, he is ever thus when one talks of whoring and Religion, but come Sir walk in, and I'le undertake my Tutor shall beg your pardon and renoun •… e his English ill-bred opinion; Nay, his English Churches too—all but his own Vicaridge.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I have better diversion Sir I thank you—come Julio, are you for a walk in the Garden of Medices Villa, 'tis hard by?—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'le wait on you—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How in the Garden of Medices Villa—but harkey Galliard, will the Ladies be there, the Curtizans! the bona roba's, the inamorata's, and the Bell ingrato's, hah?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Oh doubtless Sir;

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: I'le ene bring my Governor thither to beg his Pardon, on purpose to get an Opportunity to see the fine Women; it may be I may get a sight of my new Mistress, Dona Silvianetta whom Petro is to bring me acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: BY Heaven I will not Eat, nor sleep, nor pray for any thing but swift and sure Revenge, till I have found Marcella, that false deceiving Beauty or her Lover, my hated Rival Fillamour! who wanton in the Arms of the fair Fugitive laughs at my shamefull easiness, and crys, these joys were never meant for tame Octavio!

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: How now Crapine! What no news, no news of my Neeces yet, Marcella nor Cornelia?

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: None Sir.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: That's wondrous strange, Rome's a place of that general •… ntelligence, methinks thou might'st have news of s •… ch Trivial things as women, amongst the Cardinals •… ages; •… 'le undertake to learn the Region de stato, and present juncture of all affairs in Italy of a common Curtizan.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Sirrah sirrah, let be it your care to examine all the Nunnerys, for my own part not a petticoat shall escape me.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: My task shall be for Fillam •… re.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: I'le only make a visit to your sister Dona Laura Lucretia, and deliver her a Letter from my Nephew Julio, and return to you presently.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Stay Sir, deser your visit to my sister Laura, she is not yet to know of my being in Town, 'tis therefore I have taken a lodging in an obscure street, and am resolv'd never to be my self again till I've redeem'd my Honour. Come Sir, lets walk.—
sp.stage:
Enter to them as they are going out, Marcella and Cornelia, drest like Curtizans,
•… hilipa and attendance.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Stay stay, what women are these?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Whores Sir, and so 'tis ten to one are all the kind, only these differ from the rest in this, they generously own their trade of sin, which others deal by stealth in: they are Curtizans.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Evenings soft and calm, as happy Lovers thoughts:
And here are Groves where the kind meeting Trees
Will hid •… us from the Amourous gazing croud.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What shou'd we do there, sigh till our wandering Breath,
Has rais'd a gentle gale amongst the boughs;
To whose dull melancholly Musick, we
Laid on a Bed of Moss, and new fall'n leaves,
Will reade the dismall tale of Eccho's Love!
—No, I can make better use of Famous Ovid!
And prethee what a pox have we to do with Trees,
Flowers, Fountains, or naked statues?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But prethee mad Cornelia lets be grave and wise, at least enough to think a little.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: On what? your English Cavalier, Fillamour, of whom you tell so many dull stories of his making Love! Oh how I hate a civil whining Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And so do I, I'le therefore think of him no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Good Lord! what a damnable wicked thing is a Virgin grown up to woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why art thou such a fool, to think I love this Fillamour?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: It may be not at Rome, but at Vitterbo, where men are scarce you did; and did you follow him to Rome, to tell him you cou'd Love no more?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A too forward Maid Cornelia, hurts her own fame, and that of all her sex.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Her Sex, a pretty consideration by my youth, an Oath I shall not violate this dozen year, my sex shou'd excuse me, if to preserve their same, they expected I shou'd ruin my own quiet: in chusing an ill favourd Husband, such as Octavio before a young handsome Lover, such as you say Fillamour is.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wou'd sain perswade my self to be of thy minde,—but the World Cornelia.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hang the malicious World—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And there's such charms, in wealth and Honour too!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: None half so powerfull as Love, in my opinion, 'life Si •… ter thou art beautifull, and hast a Fortune too, which before I wou'd lay out upon so shamefull a purchase as such a Bedsellow for life as Octavio; I wou'd turn errant keeping Curtizan, and buy my better fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That word too startles me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What Curtizan, why 'tis a Noble title and has more Votaries then Religion, there's no Merchandize like ours, that of Love my sister!—and can you be frighted with the vizor, which you your self put on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twas the only disguise that cou'd secure us from the search of my Uncle and Octavio, our Brother Julio is by this too arriv'd, and I know they'l all be dilligent,—and some honour I was content to sacricise to my eternal repose.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Spoke like my sister, a little impertinent Honour, we may chance to lose 'tis true, but our right down honesty, I perceive you are resolv'd we shall maintain through all the dangers of Love and Gallantry;
—though to say truth I finde enough to do, to defend my heart against some of those Members that Nightly serinade us: and daily show themselves before our window, Gay as young Bridegrooms and as full of expectation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But is't not wondrous, that amongst all these crowds we should not once see Fillamour, I thought the charms of a fair young Curtizan, might have oblig'd him to some curiosity at least.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ay! and an English Cavalier too, a Nation so sond of all new Faces.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heaven, if I should never see him, and I frequent all publique places to meet him; or if he be gone from Rome, if he have forgot me, or some other Beauty have imploy'd his thoughts!—.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Whe if all these if's and or's come to pass, we have no more to do then to advance in this same glorious Prosession, of which now we only seem to be:—in which to give it its due, there are a thousand satisfactions to be sound, more then in a dull virtuous life! Oh the world of dark Lanthorn men we shou'd have; the Serinades, the Songs, the sighs, the Vows, the resents, the quarels, and all for a look or a smile, which you have been hitherto so cove •… oas of, that Petro swears our Lovers begins to suspect us for some honest gilts; which by some is accounted much the lewder scandal of the two,—therefore I think faith we must ene be kinde a little, to redeem our reputations.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: However we may rally, certainly there's nothing so hard to woman, as to expose her self to villainous Man.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Faith Sister, if 'twere but as easy to satisfy the nice scruples of Religion, and Honour, I should finde no great difficulty in the rest,—besides another argument I have, our money's all gone, and without a Miracle can hold out no longer honestly.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then we must sell our Jewels!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: When they are gone, what Jewell will you part with next?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then we must.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What, go home to Vit •… erbo, ask the Old Gentleman pardon, and be receiv'd to Grace again, you to the embraces of the amiable Octavio; and I to St. Teretia's, to whistle through a Grate like a Bird in a Cage,—for I shall have little heart to sing:—but come let's leave this sad talk, here's men—let's walk and gain new Conquest, I love it dearly.—
sp.stage: Enter Gall. Fill. and Jul. See the Women.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Women! and by their garbo for our purpose too—they're Curtizans, lets follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: What shall we get by gazing but disquiet, if they are fair and honest, we look and perhaps may sigh in vain; if beautiful and loose, they are not worth regarding.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Dear Notional Knight, leave your satirical Foperies, and be at least good humour'd, and let's follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'le leave you in the pursuit, and take this opportunity, to write my Uncle word of my arrival: and wait on you here anon.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Prethee do so: hah, whose that with such an equipage?
sp.stage: [Exit. Jul. Fill. and Gall. going after. Marcella and Cor. meet just entring, Laura with her Equipage, drest like a man.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Pox, let the Tradesmen ask, who cringe for such gay Customers, and follow us the women!
sp.stage: [Exit Fill. and Gall. down the scene. Lau. looking after 'em.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: 'Tis he, my Cavalier! my Conqueror: Antonio, let the Coaches wait!—and stand at distance all! Now Silvio, on thy life forget my Sex and quality, forget my useless Name of Laura Lucretia, and call me Count of—

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: What Madam?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Madam! ah foolish Boy? thy seminine courage will betray us all;—but—call me—Count—San's Gaeure;—and tell me Silvio, How is it I appear!
How dost thou like my shape—my face and dress?
My Mien and Equipage, may I not pass for man?
Looks it en I rince, and Masculine,

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Now as I live you look all over what you wish; and such, as will beget a reverance and Envy in the men, and Passion in the women, but what's the cause of all this transformation?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Love! Love! Dull boy, cou'dst thou not guess 'twas Love? that dear Englese I must enjoy my Silvio.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: What he that adores the fair young Curtizan.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: That very he, my window joyns to hers, and 'twas with charms
Which he'ad prepar'd for her, he took this heart,
Which met the wellcome Arrows in their flight.
And sav'd her from their dangers,
Oft I've returnd the vows he'as made to her
And sent him pleas'd away;
When through the Errours of the Night, and distance
He has mistook me for that happy wanton,
And gave me Language of so soft a Power,
As ne're was breath'd in vain to listening Maids.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: But with permission, Madam, how does this change of Petticote for Britches, and shifting houses too, advance that Love?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
This habit, besides many opportunities 'twill give me, of geting into his acquaintance, secures me to from being known by any of my Relations in Rome; then I have chang'd my house for one so neer to that of Silvianettas, and so like it too, that even you and I have ost mistook the entrance; by which means Love, Fortune, or
chance, may with my industry contrive some •… inde mistake that may make me happyer then the rest of woman kinde.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: But what shall be reserv'd then for Co •… nt Julio, whose last letters promise his arrival within a day or two, and whom you're thea to Marry?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Reserv'd for him! a wife! a wife my Silvio,
That unconcern'd Domestique Necessary,
Who rarely brings a heart, or takes it soon away:

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: But then your Brother Count Octavio, do you not fear his jealousie?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Octavio! Oh Nature has set his Soul and mine at odds,
And I can know no fear, but where I Love!

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: And then that thing that Ladys call their Honour—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Honour, That hated Idoll, even by those
That set it up to worship: No,
I have a Soul my Boy, and that's all Love!
And I'le the Tallent which Heaven lent improve?
sp.stage: [Going out, meets Marcella and Cornelia followed by Gall. and Fill.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Here be the Curtizans, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Hah, Silvianetta and Euphemia! pursu'd too by my Cavalier,
I'le round the Garden, and mix my self amongst 'em,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prethee Sister let's retire into the grove, to avoid the pursuit of these Cavaliers?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not I, by these killing Eyes! I'le stand my ground were there a thousand, all Arm'd with Conquering Beauty?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hah—Now on my Conscience yonders Fillamour!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha! Fillamour!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My courage fails me at the sight of him—I must retire.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And I'le too my Art of Love!
sp.stage: [Mar. retires and leans against a Tree, Cor. walks about reading.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: 'Tis she, 'tis Silvianetta! Prethee advance that thou maist behold her and renounce all honest women: since in that one young sinner there are charms, that wou'd excuse even to thee all frailty;

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: The forms of Angells cou'd not reconcile me
To women of her trade.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: This is too happy an opportunity, to be lost in convincing thy singularity,— [Gall. g •… es bowing by the si •… e of Cornelia, Fill. walks about in the Scene.—If creatures so fair and charming, as your self had any need of prayer, I shou'd believe by your profound attention you were at your Evenings Devotion.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: That you may finde your mistake, in the opinion of my charms, Pray believe I am so, and ought not to be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
I hope a Man may have leave to make his Devotions by you,
at least, without danger or offence?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I know not that, I have reason to fear your devotion may be ominous, like a Blazing Star, it comes but seldom,—but ever threatens mischief,—Pray Heaven I snare not in the calamity:

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Whe I confess Madam, my fit of zeal does not take me often, but when it does, 'tis very harmlesse and wondrous hearty.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You may begin then, I shall not be so wicked as to disturb your Orisons.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd be well assur'd of that, for mine's devotion of great necessity, and the blessing I pray infinitely for, conserves me; therefore in Christian Charity keep down your eyes, and do not ruine a young mans good intentions, unlesse they wou'd agree to send kinde looks, and save me the expence of prayer.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Which wou'd be better laid out you think upon some other blessing.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Whe faith 'tis good, to have a little bank upon occasion, though I hope I shall have no great need hereafter,—if the charming Silvianetta be but kinde, 'tis all I ask of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You're very well acquainted with my Name I find!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Your Name! 'tis all I have to live on!
Like cheerfull Birds, 'tis the first tune I sing,
To wellcome in the day:
The Groves repeat it, and the Fountains Purle it,
And every pretty sound that fills my ear,
Turns all to Silvianetta!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Galliard, look there—look on that lovely woman; 'tis Marcella! the Beautifull Marcella!
sp.stage: [Offers to run to her, Gall. holds him.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hold! Marcella! where?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: That Lady there! did'st ever see her equall?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: —Whe faith as you say Harry, that Lady is beautifull—and make us thankfull—kinde, whe 'tis Euphemia Sir, the very Curtizan, I wou'd have show'd you.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Forbear, I am not fit for mirth.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Nor I in humour to make you merry;
I tell ye—yonder woman—is a Curtizan.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Do not prophane nor rob Heaven of a Saint!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Nor you rob mankinde of such a blessing, by giving it to Heaven before its time.—I tell thee 'tis a whore! a fine desirable expensive whore.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: By Heaven it cannot be! I'le speak to her, and call her my Marcella, and undeceive thy lend opinion.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Do, salute her in good Company for an honest woman—do—and spoil her markets:—'twill be a pretty civil spightful Complement, and no doubt well taken;——come I'le convince ye Sir, [Goes and pulls Philipa.
—Harkey thou kinde help-meet for man—thou gentle childe of Night—What is the price of a Night or two of pleasure, with yonder Lady—Euphemia, I mean, that Roman Curtizan.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! a Curtizan!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sure you're a great stranger in Rome, that cannot tell her price.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I am so—Name it prethee, here's a young English purchaser—Come forward man, and cheapen for your self,—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh spare your pains, she wants no customers.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: No No, it cannot, must not be, Marcella!
She has too much Divinity about her,
Not to defend her from all imputation,
Scandal wou'd die to hear her name pronounc't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Believe me, Madam, he knows you not, I overheard all he said to that Cavalier, and finde he's much in Love!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not know me, and in love! punish him Heaven for falshood! but I'le contribute to deceive him on, and ruin him with perjury.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I am not yet convinc't, I'le try her farther! [Goes to her bowing.—but, Madam, is that Heavenly beauty purchasable? I'le pay a heart rich with such wounds, and flames.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Not forgetting the Money too good lad, or your wounds and flames will be of little use!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He tells you truth, Sir, we are not like the Ladies of your Country, who tire out their men with loving upon the square, heart for heart, till it becomes as dull as Matrimony, to women of our profession there's no Rethorick like ready Money, nor Billet-Doux like Bill of Exchange.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Oh! that Heaven shou'd make two persons so resembling,
And yet such different souls——
—'sdeath how she darts me through with every look,
But if she speak she heals the wound again:

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Hah, my Rival Fillamour here! fall on—draw Sir,—and say I gave you one advantage more and fought thee fairly.
sp.stage:
[Draws on Fill. Fill. fights him out; the Ladies run off: Gall. Falls on the followers, with whom whilst he is ingaged, Enters Julio, draws and assists him: and Laura at the same time on the other side; Enter
•… etro drest like a Civility-Master; Sir Signal and Tickletext, Sir Signal climbs a Tree; Tick. runs his head in a bush, and lies on his hands and knees, Pet. assists Gall. and fights out the Bravo's: Pet. re-Enters.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Hah my Cavalier ingag'd amongst the slaves.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: My Ladys Lovers! and set upon by Octavio! we must be dilligent in our affairs! Sir Signal where are ye! Sign •… or Tickletext! I hope they have not miscarried in the fray?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh vot Servitor vos Signoria, miscarried, no the fool has wit enough to keep out of harms way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh very discrectly done Signior.—
sp.stage: [Sees Tick. in a bush, pulls him out by the heels.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe how now Governor what afraid of swords.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: No Sir, I am not afraid of Swords, but I am afraid of danger.
sp.stage: [Enter Gall. embracing Laura! after'em, Jul. and Fill. Fill. looks about.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: This bravery Sir was wondrous!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Twas only justice Sir you being opprest with odds.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: She's gone! she's gone in Triumph with my Soul.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What was the matter Sir, how came this mischief?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Oh easily Sir; I did but look, and infinitly lov'd!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And therefore were you drawn upon, or was it some old Pique •…

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I know not Sir, Oh tell not me of quarrels.
The woman friend, the woman has undone me!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Oh a blessed hearing! I'me glad of the reformation Sir, you were so squemi •… h forsooth, that a whore wou'd not down with ye! no, 'twou'd spoil your Reputation.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: A whore! wou'd I cou'd be convine't she were so, 'twou'd call my Virtue home and make me man again!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Thou ly'st—thou'rt as weak a Brother as the best on's, and believe me Harry, these sort of Damsells are like witches, if they once get hold of a man, he's their own till the charm be ended; you guess what that is Sir?

sp.speaker: Fill.
Gall.
sp.p: Ay Gad, I'le warrant thee,—well thou shalt this night enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How, Whe faith Harry, ene the old way, I know no other. Whe thou shalt ly with her man! come let's to her.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Away, let's follow her instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Signior, I have brought Mr. Tickletext, to beg your pardon—Sir.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I've other business Sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Come let's follow him, and you my generous Cavalier, must give me leave to beg the Honour of your friendship.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: My inclinations Sir, have given you more—pray let me wait on you to your Lodgings, lest a farther insolence shou'd be offer'd you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Sir you oblige too fast;

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ah che Deavilo Ayles these hot-brain'd fellows, sure they're Drunk.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: Oh fee Signior, Drunk, for a man of Quality—'tis intollerable.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay: Whe how so Signior Morigoroso.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Imbriaco, had made it a fine speech indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe faith, and so it had, as thus,—ach Deavito Ailes these hot-brain'd fellows, sure they are imbriaco,—now wou'd not I be Drunk for a thousand Crowns: imbriacho sounds Cinqa •… t par •… ent better,—Come Noble Signior, let's Andiamo a Casa, which is as much as to say, let's amble home.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Introth, wondrous expert—Certo Signior he's an apt Schollar

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ah Sir, you shall see, when I come to my civillities—

sp.speaker: 'Pet.
sp.p: Where the first less'n you shall learn, is, how to •… ve, and how to receive, with a Bon-Grace!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: That receiving lesson I will learn my self;

sp.speaker: 'Pet.
sp.p:
This unfrequented part of the Garden, Signior will 〈◊〉 purpose as well as your Lodgings,—First then—Signiors your address, [Puts himself in the mid •… le.
[Petro bows on both sides, they do the like.—Very well! that's at the approach of any person of Quali •… y after which you must take out your Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Snuff-Box: whe we take no snuff Signior.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Then Sir by all means you must learn: for besides the mode and gravity of it, it inviveates the Peri •… ramum! that is sapientiat's the brain,—that is, inspires wit, thought, invention, understanding, and the like—you conceive me Signiors—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Most profoundly Signior.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: —Then Signiors, it keeps you in considance, and countinance! and whilst you gravely seem to take a snush, you gain time to answer to the purpose, (and in a politique posture—as thus)—to any intricate question.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Hum—
〈◊〉
I like that well; and 'twere admirable if a man were allow'd to take it when he's out in's Sermon.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Doubtless Signior you might, it helps the memory better then Rosemary, therefore I have brought each of you a Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: By no means: Excuse me Signior.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ah Bagatells Signior, Bagatells, and now Signiors, I'le teach you how to take it, with a handsome Grace, Signior your hand;—and yours Signior. [Lays snuff on their bands.—So now draw your hand to, and frow under your Noses, and snuff it hard up:—Excellent well,
sp.stage: [They dawb all their Noses, and make grimaces and sneeze.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Methinks Signior, this snuff stinks most damnably: Pray what scent do you call this?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Cackamarda Orangate, a rare perfume Ple assure ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Cackamarda Orangate, and 'twere not for the Name of Cackamarda, and so sorth, a man had as good have a Sir Reverence at his Nose.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Bonprovache—Signior, you do not understand it yet, bonprovache.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe Sir 'tis impossible to endure this same Cackamarda, Whe Assassetteda is Odoriferous to it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: 'Tis your right Dulce Piquante, believe me:—but come Signiors wipe your Noses and proceed to your giving lesson.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: As how Signior

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Whe—present we with something—that—Diamond on your finger! to shew the manner of giving handsomely: [Sir Sig. gives it him.—Oh fy, Signior—between your Finger and Thumb—thus—with your other Fingers at a distance—with a speech, and a bow.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ilustrissimo Signior, the Manifold Obligations.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now a sine turn of your hand—thus—Oh that sets off the present, and makes it sparkle in the eyes of the receiver.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: —Which you have heap't upon me,—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: There flourish again.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Obliges me to beg, your acceptance of this small present, which will receive a double Lustre from your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now kiss your fingers ends, and retire back with a bow:

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: —Most admirably perform'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Nay Sir I have docity in me, tho' I say't: come Governor let's see how you can out-do me in the Art of presenting.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Well Sir, come, your snuff-Box will serve instead of my Ring, will it not?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: By no means Sir, there is such a certain Relation between a Finger and a Ring, that no present becomes either the giving or the receiving hand half so well.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe 'twill be restor'd again, 'tis but to practice by.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ay Signior, the next thing you are to learn is to receive.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Most worthy Signior, I have so Exhausted the Cornucopia of your favours, [Flourishes]—and tasted so plenteously of the fullnesse of your Bounteous Liberallity, that to retalliate with this small Jem—is but to offer a spark, where I have received a beam of superabundant sun-shine.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Most Rhetorically perform'd, as I hope to breath, Tropes and fugers all over.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Sir Signal.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Excellent—Now let's see if you can refuse, as civilly as you gave, which is by an Obstinate denial; stand both together,—
—Ilustrious Signiors, upon my honour my little merrit has not intitled me to the Glory of so splendid an offering; Trophes worthy to be laid only at your Magnanimous feet.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ah Signior, No No,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Signior Tickletext.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Nay certo Signior!—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: With what confidence can I receive so rich a present: Signior Tickletext, ah—Signior.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: I vow Signior—I'me ashamed you shou'd offer it.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: In verity, and lo am I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: •… ardio! Baccus, most incomparable.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: But when Signior are we to learn to receive again.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh Sir that's always a lesson of it self:—but now Signiors, I'le teach you how to Act a story.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How! how Signior to Act a story?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ay Sir, No matter for words or sense, so the body perform its part well.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How, tell a story without words, whe this were an excellent devise for Mr. Tickletext, when he's to hold forth to the Congregation, and has lost his Sermon-Notes—whe this is wonderfull.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I have taught it men born deaf, and blinde,—look ye stand close together, and observe—closer yet: [Gets betweem'em.—a certain Eclejastio, Plump, and Rich— [Makes a signe of being fat. Riding along the Rode,—meets a [Galloping about the Stage. Paver strapiao,—un Pavero strapiao, Paure strapiao:—strapiao—strapiao—strapiao:— [Puts himself into the Posture of a lean Beggar; his hands right •… own by his sides,—and picks both their Pockets. Elemosuna per un •… aure strapiao, par a Moure de Dievos—at last he begs a Julio—Neinte! [Makes the fat Bishop]—then the Paure strapiao begs a Mezo Julio—[lean] Neinte [fat]—une bacio—[lean]—Niente—[fat]—at last he begs his Blessing—and see how willingly the Eclesiastico gave his Benediction; [Opening his Arms hits them both in the face.—Scusa scusa mea Patrona's—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Yes very willingly, which by the way he had never done had it been worth a farthing.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Marry I wou'd he had been a little sparing of that too, at this time,— [sneezes] a shame on't, it has stur'd this same Cackamerda again most foully.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Your pardon Signior,—but come Sir Signall—let's see how you will make this silent relation—Come stand between us two—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Nay let me alone for a memory—come.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I think I have reveng'd my Backsword-beating.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Un paureo strapado—plump and rich—no, no, the Ecclesiastico meets un paureo strapado—and begs a Julio.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh no Sir, the strapado begs the Julio.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, and the Eclesastico crys Niente— [snaps his nail. un meze Julio!—Niente—un Bacoi, Niente, your blessing then Signior Ecclesastico
sp.stage: [spreads out his arms to give his blessing—and hits Tick

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Adds me, you are all a little too liberal of this same benediction.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hah—but where's Signior Morigoroso? what is he gone?—but now I think on't 'tis a point of good manners to go without taking leave.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: It may be so, but I wish I had my Ring again, I do not like the giving lesson without the taking one, whe this is picking a mans pocket certo.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Not so Governor, for then I had had a considerable losse: look ye here,—how— [feelin •… in his Pocket] how— [in another] how—gone? gone as I live! my money Governor! all the Gold Barberacho receiv'd of my Marchant to day—all gone.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hah—and mine—all my stock, the money which I thought to have made a present to the Gentlewoman, Barberacho was to bring me too— [aside]—undone undone—Villains, Cutpurses—Cheats, oh run after him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: A Pox of all silent stories: Rogue, Thief—undone.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: HOw! the Lady whom I followed from St. Peters Church a Curtizan?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: A Curtizan my Lord, fair as the Morning, and as young.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know she's fair and young, but is she to be had boy?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: My Lord she is—her Footman told me, she was a Zittella.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How a Zittella!—a Virgin, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I cannot swear it Sir, but so he told me? he said she had a world of Lovers: her Name is Silvianetta Sir, and her Lodgings—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know't, are on the Corso; a Curtizan! and a Zittella too? a pretty contradiction! but I'le bate her the last, so I might enjoy her as the first, what ere the price be, I'me resolv'd upon the adventure; and will this minute prepare my self. [Going off, enters Mur. and Octa. —hah—does the light deceive me, or is that indeed my Uncle, in earnest conference with a Cavalier:—'tis he—I'le step aside till he's past, lest he hinders this Nights diversion:

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: I say 'twas rashly done, to fight him unexamin'd.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I need not ask, my reason has inform'd me, and I'me convinc't where ere he has conceald her, that she is fled with Fillamour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Who is't they speak of?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well well, sure my Ancestors committed some horrid crime, against Nature, that she sent this Pest of woman-kind into our Family,—two Neeces for my share,—by Heaven a proportion sufficient to undo six Generations.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hah! two Neeces, what of them?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: I am like to give a blessed account of 'em to their Brother Julio my Nephew, at his return, there's a new plague now,—but my comfort is I shall be mad and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My curiosity must be satisfied,—have patience Noble Sir,—

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Patience is a flatterer Sir,—and an Ass Sir, and I'le have none on't—hah what art thou?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Has five or six years, made ye lose the remembrance of your Nephew—Julio!

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Julio! wou'd I had met thee going to thy Grave.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why so Sir?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Your sisters Sir, your sisters are both gone.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How gone Sir?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Run away Sir, flown Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heavens! which way?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Nay, who can tell the ways of fickle women,—in short Sir, your sister Marcella was to have been Married, to this Noble Gentleman,—Nay was contracted to him, fairly contracted in my own Chappel, but no sooner was his back turn'd,—but in a pernicious Moon-light Night she shews me a fair pair of heels, with the young Baggage your other sister Cornelia, who was just come from the Monastery where I bred her, to see her sister married.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A curse upon the Sex, why must mans honour
Depend upon their Frailty?
—Come—give me but any light which way they went,
And I will trace 'em with that carefull Vengeance.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Spoke like a man, that understands his Honour,
And I can guess how we may finde the Fugitives.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Name it quickly Sir!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: There was a young Cavalier—some time at Vitterbo,
Who I confess had charms, Heaven has denied to me
That trifle Beauty, which was made to please,
Vain foolish Woman, which the brave and wise,
Want leasure to design:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And what of him!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: This fine gay thing came in your sisters way, and made that conquest Nature meant such fools for: and Sir she's fled with him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh show me the Man, the daring hardy Villain,
Bring me but in the view of my Revenge,—and if I fail to take it,
Brand me with everlasting Infamy.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: That we must leave to Fortune, and our Industry,—Come Sir, lets walk and think best what to do.—
sp.stage: [Going down the Scene, Enter Fill. and Gall.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Is not that Julio—Boy run and call him back.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Fillamour, I've heard such killing news since last I left thee.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: What prethee?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I had a sister Friend—dear as my life,
And bred with all the Virtues of her Sex;
No Vestals at the Holy fire employ'd themselves
In innocenter businesse then this Virgin;
Till Love! the Fatall Feaver of her heart,
Betraid her harmlesse hours:
And just upon the point of being Married,
The thief stole in, and Rob'd us of this treasure:
She's left her Husband, Parents, and her Honour,
And's fled with the base ruiner of her Virtue.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: And lives the Villain durst affront ye thus?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He does!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Where, in what distant World?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: What is he call'd?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know not neither,—some God direct me to the Ravisher! And if he scape my rage!
May Cowards point me out, for one of their tame herd.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: In all your quarells I must joyn my sword.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And if you want,—here's another Sir,—that though it be not often drawn in anger, nor cares to be, shall not be idle in good company.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I thank ye both, and if I have occasion, will borrow their assistance, but I must leave you for a minute, I'le wait on you anon.—
sp.stage: [They all three walk as down the street talking, Enter Laura, with her Equipage.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Beyond my wish, I'me got into his Friendship,
But oh how distant Friendship is from Love!
That's all bestowed on the fair Prostitute!
—Ah Silvio, when he took me in his Armes,
Pressing my willing Bosome to his breast,
Kissing my cheek, calling me Lovely youth,
And wondering how such Beauty, and such bravery,
Met in a Man so young! ah then my Boy!
Then in that happy minute,
How neer was I to telling all my soul,
My blushes and my sighs, were all prepar'd
My Eyes cast down my trembling lips just parting,—
But still as I was ready to begin,
He crys out Silvianetta!
And to prevent mine, tells me all his Love!
—But see—he's here.—
sp.stage: [Fill. and Gall. coming up the scene.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Come lay by all sullen unresolves! for now the hour of the Berjeare approaches, Night, that was made for Lovers!—Hah! my dear Sans Caeur? my life! my soul! my joy! Thou art of my opinion!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I'me sure I am what are it be!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Whe my Friend here, and I have sent and paid our Fine for a small Tenement of pleasure, and I'me for taking present possession;—but hold—if you shou'd be a Rivall after all!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Not in your Silvianetta! My Love has a Nice appetite,
And must be fed with high uncommon delicates,
I have a Mistress Sir, of quality!
Fair! as imagination, paints young Angells!
Wanton and gay as was the first Corina
That charm'd our best of Poets,
Young as the Spring, and cheerfull as the Birds
That wellcome in the day!
Witty as fancy makes the Revelling Gods,
And equally as bounteous when she blesses!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Ah for a fine young whore, with all these charms! but that same quality allays the joy, there's such a dam'd ado with the Obligation, that half the pleasures lost in Ceremony,—Here! for a thousand Crowns I raign alone, Revell all day in Love without controle.—But come to our business, I have given order for Musick, Dark Lanthorns, and Pistolls.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: —Death if it shou'd not be Marcella now!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Prethee no more considering,—resolve and let's about it.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: I wou'd not tempt my heart again! for Love
What ere it may be in anothers breast,
In mine, 'twill turn to a Religious fire!
And so to burn for her! a common Mistress,
Wou'd be an Infamy below her practice!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Oh if that be all, doubt not Harry but an hours conversation with Euphemia, will convert it to as lewd a flame, as a man wou'd wish.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What a coyles here about a Curtizan! what ado to perswade a man to a blessing all Rome is languishing for in vain:—Come Sir, we must deal with him, as Physitians do with peevish children, force him to take what will cure him!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: And like those dam'd Physitians, kill me for want of method, no, I know my own distemper best, and your applications will make •… e mad.

sp.speaker: Gall
sp.p: Poxon't, that one cannot love a woman like a man, but one must love like an Ass.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: S'hart, I'le be bound to ly with all the women in Rome, with less ado then you are brought to one.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hear ye that Henry, s'death art not asham'd to be instructed by one so young!—but see—the star there appears,—the star that conduct thee to the shore of bliss—
She comes let's feel thy
Heart! she comes!
So breaks the day on the glad Eastern Hills!
Or the bright God of Rays from Thetis Lap:—
A Rapture now dear lad, and then fall too, for thou art
Old dog at a long Grace.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Now I'me meer man again, with all his frailties,— [Aside.—Bright lovely creature!—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Damn it, how like my Ladys Eldest Son was that.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: May I hope my sacrifice! may be accepted by you?—by Heaven it must be she! still she appears more like.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ve only time to tell you Night approches,
And th •… n I will expect you,

sp.speaker: Crap.
