sp.p:
'Tis the, Donna Marcella on my life, with the young wild
〈◊〉 !—hah—vonders the English Cavalier too; nay then by this hand I'le be paid for all my fruitless jants: for this good news—stay let me mark the House.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now to my disguise!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And have you no kinde message to send to my heart; cannot this good Example, instruct you how to make me happy?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Faith stranger I must consider first, she's skillfull in the Mar
•… handize of hearts, and has dealt in Love with so good success hitherto, she may lose on venture, and never miss it in her stock, but this is my first, and shou'd it prove to be a bad bargain, I were undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I dare secure the goods sound,—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And I believe will not ly long upon my hands.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Faith, that's according as you'l dispose on't Madam,—for let me tell you—gad a good handsome proper fellow, is as staple a commodity as any's in the Nation,—but I wou'd be reserv'd for your own use! faith take a sample to Night, and as you like it, the whole pecce, and that's fair and honest dealing I think, or the Devils in't.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ah stranger,—you have been so over-liberal of those same samples of yours, that I doubt they have spoild the sale of the rest,—cou'd you not assord think ye, to throw in a little Love and constancy; to inch out that want of honesty of yours.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Love! oh in abundance!
By those dear Eyes, by that soft smiling Mouth;
By ever secret grace, thou hast about thee,
I love thee with a vigorous, eager passion,
—Be kinde dear Silvianetta—prethee do,
Say you believe and make me blest to Night?

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: Silvianetta! so, that's the Name she has rifl'd for Cornelia, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: If I shou'd be so kind-hearted! what good use wou'd you make of so obliging an opportunity?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: That which the happy Night was first ordain'd for.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Well Signior 'tis coming on, and then I'le try what courage the darkness will inspire me with:—till then—farwell.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Till then a thousand times adieu.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ah Madam we're undone,—yonders Crapine your Uncles Vallet.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Now a curse on him; shall we not have one Night with ou •… Cavaliers—let's retire, and continue to out-wit him, or never more pretend to't, Adieu Signior Cavalier—remember Night.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Or may I lose my sense to all Eternity.
sp.stage: [Kisses his fingers and bows, she returns it for a while.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Gods, that all this that looks at least like Love,
Shou'd be dispenc •… t to one insensible!
Whilst every sillable of that dear vallue,
Whisper'd to me, wou'd make my soul all Extasy,
—Oh spare that Treasure for a gratefull purchase;
And buy that common ware with trading Gold,
Love! is too rich a price:—I shall betray my self.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Away, that's an hereticial opinion and which this 〈◊〉
Reason must convince thee of:
That Love is Love, where ever beauty is,
Nor can the Name of whore, make beauty less.
sp.stage: Enter Marcella like a Man, with a Cloak about her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Signior, is your Name Fillamour?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: It is, what wou'd you Sir.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I have a letter for you—from Vitterbo, and your Marcella Sir.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Hah—Vitterbo! and Marcella!
It shocks me like the Ghost of some forsaken Mistress,
That met me in the way to happiness,
With some new long'd for Beauty!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now I shall try thy Virtue, and my Fate.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: What is't that checks the joy, that shou'd surprize me at the receipt of this!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How now! what's the cold fit coming on?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: I have no power to go—where this—invites me—
Which I prove, 'tis no encrease of flame that warms my heart,
〈◊〉 a new fire just kindled from those—eyes—
Whose rayes I sinde more piercing then Marcella's.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: —Ay Gad a thousand times—prethee what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh this false—souly man—wou'd I had leasure
To be reveng'd for this inconstancy!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: —But still she want's that Virtue I admire!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Virtue! s'death thou art always fumbling, upon that dull string that makes no Musick:—What Letters that? [reads.] If the first Confession I ever made of Love be gratefull to you, come arm'd to night with a friend or too; and behinde the Garden of the Fountains, you will receive—hah Marcella!—Oh damn it, from your honest woman!—Well I see the devil's never so busy with a man, as when he has resolv'd upon any goodness! s'death what a rubs here in a fair cast,—how is't man-Alegremente! bear up, defy him and all's his works.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: But I have sworn, sworn that I lov'd Marcella! and Honour Friend obliges me to go, take her away and marry her,—And I conjure thee to assist me too.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What to night, this Night, that I have given to Silvianetta! and you have promis'd to the fair—Euphemia!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: If he shou'd go, he ruins my design,
—Nay if your word Sir—be already past.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I gave my promise to Euphemia! but that to women of her trade, is easily absolv'd.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Men keep not Oaths for the sakes of the wise Magistrates, to whom they're made, but their own Honour Harry: And is't not much a greater crime to Rob a Gallant, hospitable man of his Neece, who has treated you with Confidence, and Friendship, then to keep touch with a well meaning whore, my Consciencious friend!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Infinite degrees Sir!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Besides, thou'st an hour or two good, between this and the time requir'd to meet Marcella.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Which an industrious Lover, wou'd manage to the best advantage.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: That were not given over to Virtue, and constancy—two the best excuses I know for idlenesse.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: —Yes—I may see this woman.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Whe God a marcy lad!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: —And break my chains,—if possible.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Thou wilt give a good essay to that I'le warrant thee,
Before she part with thee! come let's about it.
sp.stage: [They go out on either side of Fill. perswading him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's gone! the Curtizan has got the day.
Vice has the start of Virtue, every way,
And for one blessing honest wives obtain,
The happyer Mistress does a thousand gain!
I'le home—and practice, all their Art to prove,
That nothing is so cheaply gain'd as Love!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Stay what farce is this,—prethee let's see a little. [offering to go [Enter Sir Signal, Mr. Tickletext, with his Cloke ty'd about him, a great Ink-horn ty'd at his Girdle, and a great Folio under his Arm, Petro drest like an Antiquary.—How Now Mr. Tickletext, what drest as if you were going a Pillgrimage to Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I make no such prophane Journeys, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: But where have you been Mr. Tickletext.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe Sir, this most Reverend and Renowned Antiquary, has been showing us Monimental Rarities and Antiquities.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: 'Tis Petro that—Rogue!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p:
—But what Folio have you gotten there Sir, Knox, or Car •…
wright?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay if he be got into that heap of Nonsense, I'le steal off and undress.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: A small Vollum Sir, into which I transcribe the most memorable and remarkable transactions of the day.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: That doubtless must be worth seeing.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: [Reads] April the Twentieth, arose a very great storm of Wind, Thunder, Lightning, and Rain,—which was a shrew'd sign of foul weather.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: The 22th. 9 of our 12 chikens getting loose, flew over-bord, the other three miraculous escaping, by being eaten by me, that Morning for breakfast.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig
sp.p:
Harkey Galliard—thou art my Friend, and 'tis not like a man o •…
•… nour, to conceal any thing from on's Friend,—know then I am th •… fortunate Rascall, that ever broke bread,—I am this Nigh •…
〈◊〉 sirra—the finest, the most delicious young Harlot, Mum— 〈◊〉
•… e Rose—in all Rome! of Barberacho's acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Gall
sp.p: —H •… h—my woman on my life! and will she be kind!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Kind, hang kindnesse man, I'me resolv'd upon conquest by parly •… y force.

sp.speaker: Gall
sp.p: Spoke like a Roman of the first Race, when Noble Rapes not whin •… g Courtship, did the Lovers business.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p:
Sha Rapes man! I mean by force of mony, pure dint of Co •…
•… aith and troth: for I have given 500 Crowns enterance already, & •… ar Dios Baccus 'tis tropo Caro—tropo Caro Mr. Galliard.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And what's this high priz'd Ladys Name Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: La Silvianetta,—and Lodges on the Corso, not far from St. James's of the incurables—very well scituated in case disaster—hah.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Very well,—and did not your wise worship know, this Silvianetta was my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How! his Mistress! what a damn'd noddy was! to name her!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: De ye hear fool! renounce me this 〈◊〉 instantly, or I'le first discover it to your Governor, and then c •… t your throat Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh Doux M •… nt—dear Galliard—Renounce her,—Corpo d •… mi that I will soul and 〈◊〉 if she belong to thee man.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No more—look •… ,—look you forget her Name—or but to think of her—farewell—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Fare well quoth •… e—'tis well I had the Art of dissembling after all, here had been a •… eet Broyl upon the Coast else.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Very well, I'le trouble my self to reade no more, since I know you'l be so kinde to the world to make it p •… lique?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: At my return Sir, for the good of the Nation, I will Print it, and I think it will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: This is a precious Rogue, to make a Tutor of.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Yet these Mooncalss, dare pretend to the breeding of our youth, and the time will come, I fear, when none shall be reputed to travel like a man of quality, who has not the advantage of being impos'd upon, by one of these •… edantique Novices, who instructs the young heir, in what himself is most profoundly ignorant of.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Come, 'tis dark and time for our design,—your servant Signiors.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I'le home, and watch the kind deceiving minute, that may conduct him by mistake to me.
sp.stage: Enter Petro, like Barberacho, just as Tick. and Sir Sig. are going out.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh Barberacho! we are undone! Oh the Diavillo take that Master you sent me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Master, what Master?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe Signior Morigoroso!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Mor—oso—what shou'd he be?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: A Civillity-Master he shou'd have been, to have taught us good manners,—but the Cornuto cheated us most damnably, and by a willing mistake taught us nothing in the world but wit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh abominable knavery! whe what a kinde of man was he?—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig,
sp.p: —whe—much such another as your self:—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Higher, Signior, higher!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Aye somewhat higher—but just of his pitch.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well Sir, and what of this man?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Only pick't our pockets, that's all.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Yes, and cozen'd us of our Rings.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, and gave us Cackamarda Orangata for snuff.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: And his blessing to boot when he had done.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: A veng'ance on't, I feel it still.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Whe this 'tis to do things of your own heads, for I sent no such Signior Moroso—but I'le see what I can do to retrive m—I am now a little in haste, farwell.—
sp.stage: [Offers to go. Tick. goes out by him and jogs him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Remember to meet me—farewell Barberacho.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Barberacho—is the Lady ready?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Is your money ready?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe now, tho I am threatned, and kill'd, and beaten, and kickt about, this intrigue I must advance! [aside]—but dost think there's no danger?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What in a delicate young amorous Lady, Signior?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: No, No, mum, I don't much fear the Lady, but this same mad fellow Galliard, I hear, has a kinde of a hankering after her—Now dare not I tell him what a discovery I have made.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Let me alone to secure you, meet me in the Piatzo Despagnia, as soon as you can get your self in order; where the two fools shall meet, and preven eithers coming.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Enough,—here's a Bill for 500 Crowns more upon my Merchant, you know him by a good token, I lost the last sum you receiv'd for me, a pox of that handsell, away here's company. Ex. Pet. Enter Octavio. Now will I disguise my self, according to the mode of the Roman Inamorato's; and deliver my self upon the place appointed.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: On the Corso didst thou see 'em?

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: On the Corso my Lord, in discourse with three Cavaliers, one of which has given me many a Pistol, to let him into the Garden a Nights at Vitterbo: to talk with Don •… Marcella, from her Chamber window, I think I shou'd remember him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Oh that thought fires me, with anger fit for my Revenge, [Aside. And they're to Serinade 'em thou say'st.

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: I did my Lord! and if you can have patience till they come, you will finde your Rival in this very place, if he keep his word.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I do believe thee, and have prepared my Bravos to attack him: if I can Act but my Revenge to Night, how shall I worship Fortune! keep out of sight, and when I give the word be ready all. I hear some coming let's walk off a little.—
sp.stage: [Enter Marcella in mans clothes, and Philipa as a woman, with a Lanthorn Oct. and Crap. go off the other way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou canst never convince me, but if Crapine saw us, and gaz'd so long upon us, he must know us too, and then what hinders but by a dilligent watch about the House, they will surprize us, ere we have secured our selves from 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And how will this, exposing your self to danger prevent 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My designe now is, to prevent Fillamours coming into danger, by hindring his approach to this house: I wou'd preserve the kinde ingrate with any hazard of my own: and 'tis better to dye then fall into the hands of Octavio. I'me desperate with that thought,—and fear no danger! however be you ready at the door, and when I ring admit me.—ha—who comes here.—
sp.stage: [Enter Tickletext with a Periwig and Cravat of Sir Signals: A Sword by his side, and a dark Lanthorn, she opens hers, looks on him and goes out.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: A man! now am I though an old sinner, as timerous as a young thief, 'tis a great inconvenience in these Popish Countrys, that a man cannot have liberty to steal to a wench without danger; not that I need fear who sees me except Galliard, who suspecting my business, will go neer to think I am wickedly inclin'd, Sir Signal I have left hard at his study, and Sir Henry is no Nocturnal Inamorato, unless like me he dissemble it,—well Certo 'tis a wonderfull pleasure to deceive the World: And as a learned man well observ'd, that the sin of wenching lay in the habit only: I having laid that aside, Timothy Tickletext principal holder forth of the Covent Garden Conventicle, Chaplain of Buffoon-Hall in the County of Kent, is free to recreate himself.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Where the devil is this Fillamour? And the Musick: which way cou'd he go to lose me thus! [Looks towards the door.—he is not yet come.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Not yet come,—that must be Barberacho—where are ye honest Barberacho where are ye?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah! Barberacho? that name I am sure is us'd by none but Sir Signal and his Coxcomb Tutor, it must be one of those—where are ye Signior, where are ye? [Goes towards him, and opens the Lanthorn—and shuts it straight.—Oh 'tis the Knight,—are you there Signior?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh art thou come, honest Rascal—conduct me quickly, conduct me to the Beautifull and fair Silvian •… tta!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes, when your dogships damn'd, Silvianetta! S'death is she a whore for fools!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hah Mr. Galliard, as the devil wou'd have it:—I'me undone if he sees me!
sp.stage: [He retires hastily, Gall. gropes for him.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Where are you Fop: Buffoon! Knight! [Tickletext retiring hastily runs against Octavio, who is just entering, almost beats him down, Oct. strikes him a good blow, beats him back and draws: Tick. gets close up in a corner of the stage, Oct. gropes for him as Gall. does, and both meet and fight with each other.—What dare you draw,—you have the impudence to be valliant
then in the dark, [they pass] I wou'd not kill the Rogue,—death you can fight then, when there's a woman •… n the case!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I hope 'tis Fillamour! [aside] you'le finde I can, and possibly may spoil your making love to Night!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Egad sweet heart and t •… t may be, one civil thrust will do't:—And 'twere a damn'd rude th •… ng to disappoint so fine a woman,—therefore I'le withdraw whilst I'me well.
sp.stage: [Enter Sir Signal, with a Masquerad •… g Coat over his clothes, without a Wigg or Cravat, with a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Well I have most neatly escapt my Tutor; and in this disguise defy the devil to claim his own,—ah Caspeto de Deavilo!—What's that?
sp.stage: [Adva •… ing softly, and groping with his hands, meets the point of Oct. sword, as he is groping for Gall.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Traytor darest thou not stand my sword!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hah! swords! no Signior—scusa mea Signior,—
sp.stage: [Hops to the door: And feeling for his way with his out-strecht Arms, runs his Lanthorn in Julio's face who is just entering; finds he's oppos'd with a good push backward, and slips aside into a corner over against Tickletext: Julio meets Octavio and fights him, Oct. falls, Julio opens his Lanthorn and sees his mistake.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Is it you Sir?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Julio! from what mistake grew all this violence?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That I shou'd ask of you, who meet you arm'd against me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I find the Night has equally deceiv'd us; and you are fitly come! to share with me the hopes of dear Revenge!
sp.stage: [Gropes for his Lanthorn which is dropt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'de rather have pursu'd my kinder passion! Love! and desire! that brought me forth to Night!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I've learnt where my false Rival is to be this Evening, And if you'l joyn your sword, you'l finde it well imploy'd.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Lead on, I'me as impatient of Revenge as you.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Come this way then, you'l find more aids to serve us.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: —So! thanks be prais'd all's still again, this fright were enough to mortify any Lover of less magnanimity then my self,—well of all sins, this itch of whoring is the most hardy,—the most impudent in repulses; the most vigilant in watching, most patient in waiting, most frequent in dangers: in all disasters but disappointment, a Philosopher! yet if Barberacho come not quickly, my Philosophy will be put to't certo.
sp.stage: [This while Sir Signal i •… venturing from his post, listening and slowly advancing towards the middle of the stage.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p:
The coast is once more clear, and I may venture my carcass forth again,—though such a salutation as the last, wou'd make me very unfit for the matter in hand,—the battoon I cou'd bear with the
Fortitude and courage of Hero: But these dangerous sharps I never lov'd; what different rancounters have I met withall to Night, Corpo de me; a man may more safely pass the gulf of lyons, then convoy himself into a Bawdy house in Rome, but I hope all's past, and I will say with Alexander:—Vivat Esperance en despetto del Fatto.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sure I heard a Noise,—No 'twas only my surmise!
sp.stage: [They both advance softly, meeting just in the middle of the Stage, and coming close up to each other! both cautiously start back: And stand a tipto in the posture of fear, then gently feeling for each other, (after listening and hearing no n •… ise) draw back their hands at touching each others; and shrinking up their shoulders, make grimases of more fear!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Que Equesto.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hah a mans voice!—I'le try if I can fright him hence! [Aside. Una Malladette Spirito Incarnate!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hah, Spiritto Incarnate! that devils voice I shou'd know!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: See Signior! Una spirito! which is to say, un spiritalo, Imortallo Inc •… rporalla, Inanimate, Imaterialle, Philosophicale, Invisible—Un intelligible—Diavillo!

sp.speaker: Tick
sp.p: Ay ay, 'tis my hopefull pupill! upon the same design with me, my life on't,—Cunning young whoremaster!—I'le cool your courage—good Signior Diavillo! if you be the Diavillo I have unacertaina Imaterialle Invisible Conjuratione, that will so neatly lay your Inanimate unintelligible Diavilloship.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How! he must needs be valliant indeed that dares fight with the devil. [Endeavours to get away, Tick. beats him about the stage.—Ah Signior Signior Mia! ah—Caspeto de Baccus,—he cornuto, I am a damn'd silly devil that have no dexterity in vanishing.
sp.stage: [Gropes and finds the door—going out, meets just entring Fillamour Galliard with all the Musick—he retires and stands close.
sp.p: —Hah,—what have we here new mischief.—
sp.stage: [Tick. and he stands against each other, on either side of the stage.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Prethee how came we to lose ye?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I thought I had follow'd ye,—but'tis well we are met again, come tune your pipes,—
sp.stage: [They play a little, Enter Marcella as before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This must be he.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Come come, your Song boy your Song.
sp.stage: [Whilst'tis singing Enter Octavio, Julio, Crapine, and Bravo's!

lg.l: Il mio Core non fa per te
Il mio Core non fa per te.
•… ui non Credo alta tua fe
Nel mio Core pui viuo none
Il mio Core non fa per te.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: 'Tis they we look for, draw and be ready.——

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hah draw—then there's no safty here certo.
sp.stage: [Octavio Julio and their party draw, and fight with Fill. and Gall. Marcella ingages on their si •… e, all fight, the Musick confusedly amongst 'em; Gall. l •… ses his sword, and in the hurry gets a Base Viol, and happens to strike Tickletext, who is getting away—his head breaks its way quite through, and it hangs about his neck, they fight out.
Enter Petro with a Lanthorn. Sir Signal stands close still.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh undone, undone, where am I, where am I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Hah—that's the voice of my Amorous Ananias,—or I am mistaken—what the devil's the matter. [Opens his Lanthorn.—Where are ye Sir,—hah cuts so—what new found pillory have we here?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh honest Barberacho undo me, undo me quickly.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So I design Sir, as fast as I can—or lose my aim—there Sir there: all's well—I have set you free, come follow me the back way, into the house.
sp.stage: Enter Fillamour and Marcella, with their swords drawn Gall. after 'em.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A plague upon 'em, what a quarters here for a wench, as if there were no more i'th Nation,—wou'd I'de my sword again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Which way shall I direct him to be safer,—how is it Sir, I hope you are not hurt.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Not that I feel, what art thou asks't so kindly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A servant to the Roman Curtizan, who sent me forth to wait your coming Sir, but finding you in danger shar'd it with you,—come let me lead you into safety Sir.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Thou'st been too kinde to give me cause to doubt thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Follow me Sir, this key will give us entrance through the Garden.
sp.stage: Enter Octavio with his sword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: ! Oh what damn'd luck had I so poorly to be vanquish't when all is husht, I know he will return,—therefore I'le fix me here, till I become a furious statue—but I'le reach his heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh lamentivolo fato—What bloody Villains these Popish Itallians are.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Hah—I hear one coming this way——hah—the door opens too,—and he makes towards it—pray Heaven he be the right: for this I'me sure's the House?—Now luck an't be thy will,—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The Rogues are fled but how secure I know not,—
And I'le pursue my first design of Love,
And if this Silvianetta will be kind.—
sp.stage: [Enter Laura from the house in a Night gown.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Whi'st—who is't Names Silvianetta?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A Lover and her slave.—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh is it you,—are you escapt unhurt?
Come to my bosome—and be safe for ever.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis Love that calls, and now Revenge must stay,—this hour is thine fond Boy, the next that is my own I'le give to anger.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Oh ye pernicious pair,—I'le quickly change the Scene of Love into a ruff •… r and more unexpected entertainment.
sp.stage: [She leads Julio in,—Oct. follows close, they shut the door upon 'em. Sir Sig. thrusts out his head to hearken, hears no body and advances.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Sure the devil raigns to Night, wou'd I were shelter'd and let him raign fire and Brimstone, for pass the streets I dare not—this shou'd be the house—or here abouts I'me sure 'tis,——hah—what's this—a string—of a Bell I hope—I'le try to enter; and if I am mistaken 'tis but crying conlicentia!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Whose there?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: 'Tis I, 'tis I, let me in quickly.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Who—the English Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: The same——I am right—I see I was expected.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I'me glad you're come,——give me your hand.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: I am fortunate at last,—and therefore will say with the Famous Poet.
—No happiness •… ike that achiv'd with danger, Which once o'recome—I'le ly at Rack and Manger.

sp.stage: Enter Fillamour and Galliard, as in Silvianetta's apartment.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: —HOw s •… ndidly these Common women live,
How rich is all we meet with in this Palace,
And rather seems th' Apartment of some Prince,
Then a Receptickle for lust and shame.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: You see Ha •… y, all the keeping fools are not in our dominions but this grave this wi •… e people, are Mistress riden too.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 fear we have mistook the house, and the youth that brought us in may have deceived us, on some other design, however whilst I've this— 〈◊〉 cannot fear.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A good caution, and I'le stand upon my guard with this, but see—here's one will put us out of doubt.
sp.stage: [Pulls a pistol out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Hah! the fair Inchantress!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What on your guard my lovely Cavalier! lyes there a danger
In this Face and Eyes, that needs that rough resistance?
—Hide hide that mark of anger from my sight,
And if thou woud'st be absolute conqueror here,
Put on soft looks with Eyes all languishing,
Words tender, gentle sighs, and kind desires.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Death! with what unconcern he hears all this? art thou possest—pox why dost not answer her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hope he will not yield,—
—He stands unmov'd,—
Surely I was mistaken in this face,
And I believe in charms that have no power.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: S'death thou deservest not such a Noble creature,—
I'le have 'em both my self.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: —Yes! thou hast wonderous power,
And I have felt it long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: —I've often seen that face—but 'twas in dreams:
And sleeping lov'd Extreamly!
And waking—sigh't to find it but a dream,
The lovely Phantom vanish't with my slumbers,
But left a strong Idea on my heart;
Of what I finde in perfect Beauty here,
—But with this difference, she was Virtuous too!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What silly she was that!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: She whom I dream't I Lov'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You only dream't that she was Virtuous too!
Virtue it self's a dream of so slight sorce,
The very •… uttering of Loves wings destroys it,
Ambition, or the meaner hope of interest, wakes it to nothing,
In men a feeble Beauty, shakes the dull slumber off,—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Egad she argues like an Angell Harry!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: —What hast thou'st made, to damn thy self so young!
Hast thou been long thus wicked? hast thou sin'd past Repentance,
Heaven may do much, to save so fair a Criminal,
Turn yet and be forgiven!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What a pox dost thou mean by all this canting?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A very pretty Sermon, and from a priest so gay,
It cannot chuse but edify.
Do Holy men of your Religion Signior, wear all this Habit,
Are they thus young, and lovely? sure if they are,
Your Congregation's all compos'd of Ladys,
The Layety must come abroad for Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Oh that this charming woman were but honest!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: 'Twere better thou wer't damn'd; honest!
Pox thou dost come out with things so malapropo—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come leave this Mask of foolish modesty,
And let us hast where Love and Musick call's;
Musick! that heightens Love! and makes the soul,
Ready for soft impressions!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So, she will do his business with a Vengeance!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Plague of this tempting woman she will ruin me!
I finde weak Virtue melt from round my heart,
To give her Tyrant Image a Possession:
So the warm Sun, thaws Rivers Icy tops,
Till in the stream he sees his own bright face!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Now he comes on apace,—how is't my friend,
Thou stand st as thou'dst forgot thy business here!
—The woman Harry! the fair Curtizan!
Canst thou withstand her charms? I've business of my own,
Prethee fall too—and talk of Love to her.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Oh I cou'd talk Eternity away,
In nothing else but Love!—cou'dst thou be honest?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Honest! was it for that you sent two thousand Crowns.
Or did believe that trifling sum sufficient,
To buy me to the slavery of honesty.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hold there my brave Virago.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: No, I wou'd sacrifice a Nobler Fortune,
To buy thy Virtue home!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What shou'd it idling there!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Whe—make thee constant to some happy man,
That wou'd adore thee for't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Unconscionable! constant at my years?
—Oh t'were to cheat a thousand!
Who between this and my dull Age of Constancy,
Expect the distribution of my Beauty.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: 'Tis a brave wench,—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Yet charming as thou art, the time will come
When all that Beauty like declining flowers,
Will wither on the stalk,—but with this difference,
The next kinde Spring, brings youth to flowers again,
But faded Beauty never more can bloom,
—If intrest make thee wicked, I can supply thy pride.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Curse on your necessary trash!—which I despise, but as 'tis usefull to advance our Love!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Is Love thy business, who is there born so high,
But Love and Beauty equals,
And thou maist chuse from all the wishing world?
This wealth together wou'd inrich one man,
Which dealt to all wou'd scarce be Charity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Together! 'tis a Mas wou'd Ransome King's!
Was all this Beauty given, for one poor petty Conquest;
—I might have made a hundred hearts my slaves,
In this lost time of bringing one to Reason.—
Farewell thou dull Philosopher in Love;
When Age has made me wise,—I'le send for you again.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: By this good lighta Noble glorious Whore!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Oh stay,—I must not let such Beauty fall,
—A whore—consider yet, the charms of Reputation:
The ease, the quiet and content of innocence,
The awfull Reverence, all good men will pay thee,
Who as thou art will gaze without respect,
—And cry—what pitty 'tis she is—a whore—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O you may give it what course Name you please;
But all this youth and Beauty ne're was given,
Like Gold to Misers, to be kept from use.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Lost lost,—past all Redemption.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Nay, Gad thou shalt not lose her so,—I'le fetch her back,
And thou shalt ask her pardon.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: By Heaven 'twas all a dream! an Aiery dream!
The Visionary pleasure disappears,—and I'me my self again,
—'le fly, before t • e drowsy fit ore'take me.
sp.stage: [Going out, Eeter Gall. and then Marcella.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Turn back—she yields, she yields to pardon thee,—gon—
Nay hang me if ye part.
sp.stage: [Runs after him, still his Pistol in his hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Gon—I have no leasure now for more dissembling.
sp.stage: Enter Petro, leading in Mr. Tickletext, as by dark.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Remain here Signior whilst I step and fetch a light.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Do so, do so honest Barberacho!—well my escape even now •… rom Sir Signal was Miraculous! thanks to my prudence and prowess, had he discover'd me, my dominion had ended; and my Authority been of non effect certo.
sp.stage: [Philipa at the door puts in Sir Signal.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now Signior yo're out of danger, I'le fetch a Candle, and let •… y Lady know of your being here!
sp.stage: Enter Petro with a light, goes between 'em and starts.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sir Signal!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: My Governor!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: The two fools met! a pox of all ill luck: now shall I lose my credit with both my wise Patrons, my Knight I cou'd have put off, with a small Harlot of my own, but my Levite having seen my Lady Cornelia that is La Silvianetta,—None but that Susanna wou'd satisfy his Eldership: but now they have both sav'd me the labour of a farther invention to dispatch 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: I perceive my Governor's as much confounded as my self;—I'le take advantage by the forelock, be very impudent and put it upon him faith,—Ah Governor, will you never leave your whoring! never be stayd, sober and discreet as I am

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: So so, undone undone, just my Documents to him.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: And must I neglect my pretious studys, to follow you, in pure zeal and tender care of your person! will you never consider where you are? in a lewd Papish Country! amongst the Romish Heathens,—and for you a Governor, a Tutor, a director of unbridled youth, a Gown-man, a Polititian, for you I say to be taken at this unrighteous time of the Night, in a flaunting Cavaliero dress, an unlawful weapon by your side, going the high way to Satan to a Curtizan! and to a Romish Curtizan! Oh abomination, Oh Scandalum infiniti.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Paid in my own Coyn!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So, I'le leave the devil to rebuke sin, and to my young Lady, for a little of her assistance, in the management of this affair.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: —I do confess,—I grant ye I am in the house of a Curtizan, and that I came to visit a Curtizan, and do intend to visit each Night a several Curtizan:—till I have finisht my work.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Every Night one! Oh glutton!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: —My great work of Conversion,—upon the whole Nation, Generation, and Vocation, of this wicked provoking sort of womankinde; call'd Curtizans:—I will turn 'em—yes I will turn 'em,—for 'tis a shame that Man—shou'd bow down to those that worship Idols!—and now I think Sir, I have sufficiently explain'd the business in hand,—as honest Barberacho is my witness!—And for you—to—scandalize—me—with so naughty an interpretation—afflicteth me wonderfully.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: —Alas poor Mr. Tickletext, now as I hope to be sav'd it grieves my heart to see him weep,—faith and troth now, I thought thou had'st some Carnal assignation,—but nere stir I beg thy pardon and think thee as innocent as my self, that I do—but see the Ladys, here—s'life dry your Eyes man!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I cou'd beat thee for being thus mistaken,—and am resolv'd to flatter him into some mischief, to be Reveng'd on 'em for this disappointment, go you and watch for my Cavalier the while.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Is she come—Nay then turn me loose to her.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My Cavalier!
sp.stage: [Addressing to Sir Sig. Tick. pulls him by and speaks.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: —Lady.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: You Sir, whe who the devil made you a Cavalier,—most Potentisimo Signiora, I am the man of Title, by Name Sir Signal Buffoon, sole Son and heir to Eight Thousan •… pound a year.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh Sir, are you the man she looks for?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: I Sir, No Sir, I'de have ye to know Sir, I scorn any woman be she never so fair, unless her designe be honest and Honourable!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: The man of all the World I've chosen out, from all the wits and Beauties I have seen;—to have most finely beaten!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How! in Love with me already,—she's damnable handsome too, now wou'd my Tutor were hang'd a little for an hour or two, out of the way.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why fly you not into my Arms, [she approching, he shuning These Arms that were design'd for soft embraces?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, and if my Tutor were not here, the devil take him that wou'd hinder'em,—and I think that's civil egad!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Whe how now Barberacho, what am I cuz •… nd then, and is Sir Signal the Man in savour!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Lord Signior, that so wise a man as you cannot perceive her meaning; for the devil take me if I can,— [Aside.]—Whe this is done to take off all suspition from you—and lay it on him;—don't you conceive it Signior!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Yes honest Rogue,—Oh the witty wagtail,—I have a part to play too, that shall confirm it—young Gentlewoman.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ah bell ingrate, is't thus you recompence my suffering Love •… ? to fly this beauty so ador'd by all, that slight the ready conquest of the world to trust a heart with you,—ah—Traditor Cruella.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Poor heart, it goes to the very soul of me to be so coy and scornsull to her that it does, but a pox on't her over-fondness will discover all.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Fly, fly, young man! whilst yet thou hast a spark of virtue shining in thee, fly the temptations of this young hypocrite; the love that she pretends with so much zeal and ardour, is indecent, unwarrantable, and unlawful! first indecent as she is woman—for thou art woman—and beautiful woman—yes, very beautifull woman! on whom nature hath shew'd her heighth of excellence in the out-work, but, left the in unfinisht, imperfect and impure.

sp.speaker: Cor
sp.p: Heavens, what have we here!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: A pox of my Sir Dominie, Now is he beside his Text, and will spoil all.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Secondly, Unwarrantable; by what authority dost thou seduce with the allurements of thine eyes, and the conjurements of thy tongue, the wastings of thy hands, and the tinklings of thy feet, the young men in the Villages?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sirrah! how got this madman in? seize him, and take him hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Corpo de mi my Governour tickles her notably i'saith—but had he let the care of my soul alone to night, and have let me taken care of my body, 'twould have been more material at this time.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Thirdly, Unlawful—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Quite distracted! in pity take him hence, and leade him into •… nesse, 'twill sute his madness best.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How, distracted! take him hence!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: This wa •… l •… cky—I knew she wou'd come again—take him hence—yes, into her bed-chamber—pretty device to get you to herself Signior.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Why but is it—nay, then I will facillitate my departure—therefore I say—oh most beautifull and tempting woman—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Away with him, give him •… ern straw and darknesse,
And cha •… him fast for fear of further mischief.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: She means for fear of losing ye.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Ah baggage! as fast as she will in those pretty arms,

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hold, hold man, Mad said ye—ha, ha, ha—mad! whe we have a thousand of these in England that go loose about the streets, and pass with us for as sober di •… creet religious persons—As a man shall wish to talk nonsense withall.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: —You are mistaken Signior, I say he is mad—stark mad,

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Prethee Barberacho what dost thou mean—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To rid him hence that the may be alone with you—'slife Sir, you're madder then he—don't you con •… eive—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay, ay! n •… y, I confe •… se, Ill •… issima Signiora, my Governour has a Fit that ta •… es him now and then, a kinde of a frenzy,—a figary—a whim •… e—a m •… ot that bites always at naming of Popery:—so—he's •… one.—Bellissimo Signiora,—you have most artificially remov'd him—and this extraordinary proof of your affe •… on is a signe of some small kinden •… se towards me, and though I was something •… oy and reserv'd before my Governour, Excellentissimo Signiora, let me te •… l you, your love is not cast away.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh Sir you blesse too fast! but will you ever love me—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Love thee! I and li •… with thee too, Most Magnanimous Signiora, and beget a whole Race of Roman Julius Caesa •… s upon thee; nay, now we're alone, turn me loose to impudence, i'saith.
sp.stage: [ruffles her, •… nter Philipa in haste, shutting the door after her

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh Madam here's the young mad English Cavalier got into the house, and will not be deny'd seeing you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This was lucky!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How the mad English Cavalier! If this shou'd be our young Count Galliard now—I were in a sweet taking—oh I know by my fears 'tis he; oh prethee what kinde of a manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A handsome—resolute—brave—bold—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh enough enough—Madam—I'le take my leave—I see you are—something busie at present,—and I'le—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not for the World,—Philipa—bring in the Cavalier—that you may, see there's none here fears him Signior.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh hold hold,—Madam you are mistaken in that point, for to tell you the truth, I do fear,—having—a certain—aversion or Antipathy,—to—Madam—a Gentleman—whe Madam they're the very Monsters of the Nation, they devour every day a Virgin.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Good Heavens! and is he such a Fury!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh and the veryest Belzebub,—besides Madam he vow'd my Death, if ever he catch me neer this house, and he ever keeps his word in cases of this Nature,—Oh that's he, [Knocking at the door I know it by a certain trembling instinct about me,—Oh what shall I do.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Whe—I know not,—can you leap a high window?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: —He knocks again,—I protest I'me the worst Vaulter in Christendom,—have ye no moderate danger,—between the two extreams of the window or the mad Count? no Closet,—fear has dwindl'd me to the scantling of a Mousehole.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: —Let me see,—I have no leasure to pursue my Revenge farther, and will rest satisfy'd with this,—for this time— [Aside.—Give me the Candle,—and whilst Philipa is conducting the Cavalier to the Alcove by dark,—you may have an opportunity to slip out,—perhaps there may be danger in his being seen,— [Aside.—farewell fool.—
sp.stage: [Ex. Cornelia with the Candle, Phil. goes to the door, lets in Gall. takes him by the hand.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Pox on't my Knights bound for Vitterbo, and there's no perswading him into sase harbour again,—he has given me but two hours to dispatch matters here,—and then I'me to imbark with him upon this new discovery of honourable Love, as he calls it, whose adventurers are sools, and the returning Cargo, that dead Commodity call'd a wife! a Voyage very sutable to my humour,—who's there?—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A Slave of Silvianetta's, Sir give me your hand.—
sp.stage: [Ex. Over the stage. Sir Sig. goes out softly.
[The Scene changes to a Bed Chamber Alcove, Petro leading in Tickletext.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now Signior you're safe and happy; in the Bed-Chamber of your Mistress.—who will be here immediately I'me sure, I'le fetch a light and put you to bed in the mean time.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Not before supper I hope honest Barberacho!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh Signior that you shall do lying, after the manner of the Ancient Romans.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Certo, and that was a marevllous good lazy custome.
sp.stage: Enter Philipa with Galliard by dark.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My Lady will be with you instantly.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hah, sure I heard some body come softly in at the door: I hope 'tis the young Gentlewoman!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Silence! and Night! Love and dear opportunity!
Joyn all your aids to make my Silvia kinde,
For I am fild with the expecting bliss,
sp.stage: [Tick. thrusts his head out to listen.
sp.l: And much delay, or disappointment kills me.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Disappointment kills me,—and me too certo.—'tis she.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Oh haste my sair, haste to my longing Arms,—
Where are you dear and lovely st of your Sex?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: That's I, that's I, mi Alma! mea core mea vita!—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah—art thou come my life! my soul! my joy!— [Goes to embrace, Tick. they meet and kiss.—S'death what's this a bearded Mistress! Lights lights there, quickly lights,—Nay curse me if thou scap'st me.—
sp.stage: [Tick. struggles to get away, he holds him by the Cravat and Periwig, Enter Petro with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Barberacho,—consound him 'tis the sool! whom I found this Evening about the House, hovering to roost him here!—hah—what the devil have I caught—a Tarter? Escap't again! the devil's his confederate.—
sp.stage: [Pet. puts out the Candle, comes to Tick. unties his Cravat behind, and he slips his head out of the Periwig and gets away, leaving both in Gall.'s hands.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I'le leade you a back pair of stairs through the Garden.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh any way to save my Reputation—oh—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Let me but once more grasp thee, and thou shalt finde more safety in the Devils clutches! none but my Mistress serve ye.
sp.stage: [Pet. with Tick. running over the stage, Gall. after'em, with the Cravat and Perewig in one hand, his Pistol in t'other.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mercy upon us, what's the matter—what noise is this—hah a Pistol—what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Oh save me, gentle devil, save me, the stairs are fortify'd witk Canons and double Culverins; I'me pursu'd by a whole Regiment of arm'd men! here's gold, gold in abundance! save me—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What Canons? what arm'd men?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p:
Finding my self pursu'd as I was groping my way through the Hall, and not being able to finde the door, I made towards the
stairs again, at the foot of which I was saluted with a great gaun—a pox of the courtesie.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Where are ye Knight, buffoon, dog of Egypt?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Thunder and Lightning? 'tis Galliards voice—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Here, step behinde this hanging—there's a Chimney which may shelter ye till the storm be over,—if you be not smother'd before.
sp.stage: [Puts hi •… behinde the Arras,—Enter Gall. as before, and Corn. at the other door.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Havens! what rude noise is this?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Where have you hid this fool, this lucky fool?
He whom blinde chance, and more ill-judging woman
Has rais'd to that degree of happinesse
That witty men must sigh and toyl in vain for.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Wat sool, what happinesse?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Cease cunning false one to excuse thy self,
See here the Trophees of your shameful choice,
And of my ruine, cruel—fair—deceiver!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Deceiver Sir, of whom—in what despairing minute did I swear to be a constant Mistress? to what dull whining Lover did I vow and had the heart to break it.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Or if thou hadst, I know of no such dog as wou'd believe thee; no, thou art false to thy own charms, and hast betray'd'em
sp.l: To the possession of the vilest wretch
That ever Fortune curst with happiness;
False to thy joys, false to thy wit and youth
All which thou'st damn'd with so much careful industry
To an eternal fool,
That all the arts of love can ne're redeem thee!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Meaning me, meaning me:
sp.stage: [Peeping out of the Chimny his face blackt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A sool, what indiscretion have you seen in me, shou'd make ye think I wou'd choose a witty man for a lover, who perhaps loves out his moneth in pure good husbandry, and in that time does more mischief then a hundred fools; ye conquer without resistance, ye treat without pity, and triumph without mercy; and when you're gone, the world crys—she had not wit enough to keep him, when indeed you are not sool enough to be kept! thus we forfeit both our Liberties and discretion with you villanous witty men; for wisedom is but good success in things, and those that fail are fools!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Most gloriously disputed!
You're grown a Machivillian in your Art.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Oh necessary Maxims only, and the first Politiques we learn from observation—I've known a Curtezan grown infamous, despis'd, decay'd, and ruin'd, in the possession of you witty men, who when she
had the luck to break her chains, and cast her net for fools, has liv'd in state, finer then Brides upon their wedding-day, and more profuse then the young amorous Coxcomb that set her up an idoll.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Well argu'd of my side, I see the Bagage loves me!
sp.stage: [Peeping out with a face more smutted.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: And hast thou! oh, but prethee Jilt me on,
And say thou hast not, destin'd all thy charms,
To such a wicked use;
Is that dear Face and Mouth for slaves to kiss:
Shall those bright Eyes be gaz'd upon, and serve
But to reflect the Images of fools?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: That's I still.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Shall that soft tender bosome be approcht,
By one who wants a Soul, to breathe in languishment,
At every kiss that presses it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Soul, what a pox care I for Soul,—as long as my person is so Amiable.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: —No, Renounce that dull discretion that undoes thee,
Cunning is cheaply to be wise, leave it to those that have
No other powers to gain a Conquest by,
It is below thy charms;—
—Come swear,—and be forsworn most damnably,—
Thou hast not yielded yet; say 'twas intended only,
And though thou ly'st, by Heaven I must believe thee,—
—Say,—hast thou—given him—all?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I've done as bad, we have discourst th'affair,
And 'tis concluded on.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: As bad! by Heaven much worse! discours'd with him,
Were't thou so wretched, so depriv'd of sense,
To hold discourse with such an Animal?
Damn it! the sin is ne're to be forgiven!
—Had'st thou been wanton to that lewd degree,
By dark he might have been conducted to thee;
Where silently he might have serv'd thy purpose,
And thou had'st had some poor excuse for that!
But bartering words with fools admits of none.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I grant ye,—had I talk't •… nse to him,—which had been enough to have lost him for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Poor Devil, how fearfull 'tis of losing me!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: That's some atonement for thy other sins,—come break thy word and wash it quite away.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: That cogging won't do my good friend, that won't do.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Thou shalt be just and perjur'd, and pay my heart the debt of Love you owe it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And wou'd you have the heart—to make a whore of me?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: With all my Soul, and the Devils in't if I can give thee a greater proof of my passion.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I rather fear you wou'd deboch me, into that dull slave call'd a wife:

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: A wife! have I no Conscience, no Honour in me!
Prethee believe I wou'd not be so wicked,—
No,—my desires are generous! and Noble,
To set thee up, that glorious insolent thing,
That makes mankinde such slaves! almighty Curtizan!
—Come! to thy private Chamber let us haste,
The sacred Temple of the God of Love!
And consecrate thy power!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay, do you take me then for what I seem!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I'me sure I do! and wou'd not be mistaken for a Kingdome! But if thou art not! I can soon mend that fault, And make thee so,—come—I'me impatient to begin the Experiment

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nay then I am in carnest,—hold mistaken stranger!—I am of Noble birth! and shou'd I in one hapless loving minute, destroy the Honour of my House, ruin my youth and Beauty! and all that virtuous Education, my hoping parents gave me?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Pretty dissembl'd pride and innocence! and wounds no less then smiles!—come let us in,—where I will give thee leave to frown and Jilt, such pretty srauds advance the appetite.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: By all that's good I am a Maid of Quality! Blest with a Fortune equal to my Birth!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: I do not credit thee, or if I did!
For once I wou'd dispence with Quality,
And to express my Love! take thee with all these faults!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And being so, can you expect I'le yield?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: The sooner for that Reason if thou'rt wise;
The Quality will take away the scandal,—
Do not torment me longer.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay and be undeceiv'd,—I do conjure ye.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Art thou no Curtizan?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not, on my life nor do intend to be!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No prostitute! nor dost intend to be?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: By all that's good, I only feign'd to be so!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: No Curtizan! hast thou deceiv'd me then?
Tell me thou wicked—honest couzening Beauty!
Why did'st thou draw me in, with such a fair pretence,
Why such a temping preface to invite,
And the whole piece so useless and unedifying?
—Heavens! not a Curtizan!
Why from thy window did'st thou take my vows,
And make such kinde returns? Oh damn your quality, what honest
Whore but wou'd have scorn'd thy cunning.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I make ye kinde returns!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: —Perswade me out of that too! 'twill be like thee!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: By all my wishes I never held discourse with you—but this Evening since I first saw your face!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Oh the Impudence of Honesty and quallity in woman!
A plague upon 'em both, they have undone me,
Bear witness Oh thou gentle Queen of night,
Goddess of shades, ador'd by Lovers most;
How oft under thy covert she has damn'd her self,
With feigned love to me!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Heavens! this is Impudence, that power I call to witness too how damnably thou injur'st me;

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: You never from your Window talk't of love to me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So, nor you're no Curtizan;

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No by my life!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So, nor do intend to be, by all that's good;

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: By all that's good never.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So,—and you are reall honest, and of quallity?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Or may I still be wretched!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So, then farewell honesty and quallity!—S'death what a night, what hopes, and what a Mistriss; have I all lost for honesty and quallity!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: I will be wreck't first,—let go thy hold!
—Unless thou wouldst repent.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I cannot of my fixt resolves for Virtue!
—But if you could but—love me—Honourably—
For I assum'd this habit and this dress—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To cheat me of my heart the readyest way! And now like Gaming Rooks, unwilling to give o're till you have hook't in my last stake my body too, you couzen me with honesty,—oh Damn the dice—Ple have no more on't I, the game's too deep for me! unless you play'd upon the square, Or I cou'd cheat like you—farewell Quallity!—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He's gone, Phillipa run and fetch him back; I have but this short night allow'd for Liberty! Perhaps to morrow I may be a slave? [Ex. Phill. —Now a my Conscience there never came good of this troublesome virtue—hang't I was too serious, but a Devil on't he looks so Charmingly—and was so very pressing I durst trust my gay Humour and good Nature no farther!
sp.stage: [She walks about, Sir Signal peeps and then comes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: He's gone!—so—ha ha ha—as I hope to breath Madam, you have most neatly dispatcht him; poor fool—to compare his wit and his person to mine.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hah, the Coxcombe here still.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Well this Countenance of mine never fail'd me yet:

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ah—
sp.stage: [Looking about on him sees his face black squeeks and runs away.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ah, Whe what the Deavilo's that for,—Whe 'tis I, 'tis I m •… st Serenissimo Signiora!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What noise is that, or is't some new designe. To fetch me back again?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How! Galliard return'd!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah! what art thou? a •… ortall or a Devil?

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How! not know me? now might I pass upon him most daintily for a Devil, but that I have been beaten out of one Devilship already, and dare venture no more Conjurationing.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Dog, what art thou—not speak! Nay then I'le inform my self, and try if you be flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: No matter for all this—'tis better to be kick't then discovered, for then I shall be kill'd!—and I can sacrifice a limb or two to my reputation at any time!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Death, 'tis the fool, the fool for whom I am abus'd and jilted, 'tis some revenge to disappoint her cunning, and drive the slave before me—Dog! were you her last reserve.—
sp.stage: [kicks him, he keeps in his cry.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Still I say Mum!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: The Asse will still appear through all disguises,
Nor can the Devils shape secure the fool—
sp.stage: [Kicks him he runs out as Cor. enters and holds Gall.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hold Tyrant—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Oh Women! Women! fonder in your Appetites Then Beasts; and more unnatural!
For they but couple with their kinde, but you Promiscuously shuffle your Brutes together

The sop of business with the lazy Gown-man—the learned Asse with the Illiterate wit. The empty coxcombe with the Pollititian, as Dull and insignificant as he; from the gay fool made more a beast by fortune to all the loath'd infirmities of Age!
—Farewell—I scorn to crowd with the dull Herd! Or graze upon the common where they batten—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: I know he loves, by this concern I know it,
And will not let him part disatisfy'd!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: —By all that's good I love him more each [Enter Marcella. moment, and know he's destin'd to be mine.—
—What hopes Marcella, what i'st we next shall do?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fly to our last reserve, come let's haste and dress! in that disguise we took our flight from Vitterbo in,—and somthing—I resolve!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My soul informs me what!—I ha't! a project worthy of us both—Which whilst we dress I'le tell thee,—and by which My dear Marcella we will stand or fall, 'Tis our last stake we fet; and have at all.—

sp.stage: Enter Petro, Tickletext, from the Garden.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: HAste honest Barberacho, before the day discover us to the wicked world, and that more wicked Galliard!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well Signior, of a bad turn 'twas a good one, that he took you for Sir Signal! the scandal lys at his door now Sir,—so the Ladders fast, you may now mount and away.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Very well go your ways, and commend me honest Barberacho to the young Gentlewomen! and let her kno •… as soon as I may be certain to run no hazard in my Reputation, I'le visit her again!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'le warrant ye Sigmor for the future!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: So, now get you gone lest we be discover'd!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Farewell Signior, a bon viage.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: 'Tis marvellous dark, and I have lost my Lanthorn in the fray! [Groping]—hah—where abouts am I—hum—what have we here!—ah help help help! [stumbles at the Well, gets hold of the rope and slides down in the Bucket. I shall be drown'd, fire! fire, fire, for I have water enough! Oh for some house,—some street, nay wou'd Rome it self were a second time in flames, that my deliverance might be wrought by the necessity for water,—but no human help is nigh—oh.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p:
Did ever any Knight adventurer, run through so many disasters in one Night! my worshipful carkass has been cudgel •… d most plentifully, first bang'd for a coward, which by the way was none of my fault, I cannot help Nature! then clawd away for a Diavillo! there I was the fool! but who can help that too! frighted with Gall's coming into an Ague, then chimney'd into a Feavor, where I had a fine regale of soot, a perfume which nothing but my Cacamarda Orangate cou •… d excell! and which I finde by— [snufs] my smelling has defac'd Natures mage, and a second time made me be suspected for a devil!—let me see,— [Opens his Lanthorn and looks on his hands
—'tis so—I am in a clenly pickle! if my face be of the same peice, I am fit to scare away old Belzebub himselfe faith: [Wipes his face.—Ay—'tis so—like to like quoth the devil to the Collier! well I'le home, scrub my self clean if possible, get me to bed, devise a handsome lye to excuse my long stay to my Governor and all's well, and the man has his Mare again! [shuts his Lanthorn and gropes away, runs against the Well.—que questo [feels gently.] make me thankfull 'tis substantial wood! by your leave— [Opens his Lanthorn. how! a Well! sent by providence that I may wash my self, lest people smoke me by the scent, and beat me anew for stinking: [sets down his Lanthorn, pulls of his Masking coat, and goes to draw water. 'Tis a damnable heavy Bucket, now do I fancy I shall look when I am washing my self, like the signe of the Labour in vain.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: So my cry is gone forth, and I am delivered by Miracle from this Dungeon of death and darkness: this cold Element of destruction.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hah—sure I heard a dismal hollow voice.—
sp.stage: [Tick. appears in the Bucket, above the Well.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: What art thou com'st in charity.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ah le Diavillo! le Diavillo! le Diavillo.— [Lets go the Bucket, and is running frighted away. Enter Fillamour and Page, he returns.—How a man! was ever wretched wite so miserable, the devil at one hand, and a Roman Night-walker at the other! which danger shall I choose!—
sp.stage: [Gets to the door of the house.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: So, I am got up at last—thanks to my Knight, for I am sure 'twas he! hah he's here—I'le hear his business.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: Confound this woman! this bewitching woman,
I cannot shake her from my sullen heart,
Spight of my Soul I linger here abouts;
And cannot to Vitterbo.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Very good! a dainty Rascall this!
sp.stage: Enter Galliard with a Lanthorn, as from Silvia's house, held by Philipa.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: —Hah who's this coming from her house, perhaps 'tis Galliard!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No Argument shall fetch me back by Heaven?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: 'Tis the mad Rogue!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh Lord 'tis Galliard! and angry too, now cou'd I but get off and leave Sir Signal to be beaten, 'twere a rare project,—but 'tis impossible without discovery.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: But will you hear her Signior!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: That is, will I lose more time about her! plague on't I have thrown away already such Songs, and sonets, such Madrigalls and •… osies, such Night walks, sighs, and direfull Lovers looks, as wou'd have mollify'd any woman of Conscience and Religion! and now to be popt 'ith mouth with Quality! well if ever you catch me lying with any but honest well meaning Damzells hereafter hang me:—farewell old secret farewell! [Ex. Philipa. —Now am I asham'd of being cuzend so damnably, Fillamour that virtuous Rascall will so laugh at me! s'heart cou'd I but have debaucht him, we had been on equall terms,—but I must help my self with lying, and swear I have—a—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: You shall not need, I'le keep your counsel Sir!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah—este vous la!—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How Fillamour all this while, some comfort yet, I am not the only professor that dissembles! but how to get away.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Oh Harry, the most damnably defeated!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Hold! what noise is that! two men coming this way as from the house of the Curtizans.
sp.stage: [Enter Julio backwards fighting Octavio and bravo' •… !

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah on retreating,—sdeath I've no sword!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Here's one! I'le take my Pages!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Now am I mad for mischief, here hold my Lanthorn Boy!
sp.stage: [They fight on Julio's side, and fight Octavio out at tother side! Enter Laura a •… d Sabina! at the sore-door—which is the same, where Sir Signal stands, Tick. groping up that way! finds Sir Sig. just entering in: Lau. and Sab. pass over the stage.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Hah a door open! I care not who it belongs too, 'tis better dying within doors like a man then in the street like a dog!
sp.stage: [Going in Tick. in great fear comes up and pulls him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Signior! a gentle Signior, whoe're ye are that owns this Mansion, I beseech you to give protection to a wretched man! half dead with fear and injury!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Nay, I defy the devil to be more dead with fear then I!—Signior you may enter! perhaps 'tis some body that will make an excuse for us both,—but hark they return!
sp.stage: [And both go in: just after Laura and Sabina enter.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He's gone! he's gone! perhaps for ever gone,—tell me thou silly manager of Love! how got this Ruffian in, how was it possible without thy knowledge,—he cou'd get admittance.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p:
Now as I hope to live and learn I know not Madam! unless he follow'd you when you let in the Cavalier, which being by dark he
easily conceal'd himself; no doubt some Lover of the Silvianetta's who mistaking you for her! took him too for a Rival!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: 'Tis likely, and my Fortune is too blame, my cursed Fortune
Who like Misers, deals her scanty bountys with so slow a hand,
That or we dy before the blessing falls,
Or have it snatcht ere we can call it ours!
To have him in my house, to have him kinde!
Kind as young Lovers when they meet by stelth:
As fond as Age to Beauty! and as soft,
As Love and wit cou'd make impatient youth,
Preventing even my wishes and desires,
—Oh Gods! and then! even then to be defeated,
Then when our vows, had made our freedome lawfull!
What Maid cou'd suffer a surprise so cruel!
—The day begins to break,—go search the streets,
And bring me news he's safe or I am lost.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Galliard! where art thou!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Here safe and by thy side.—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis he!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Who ere he were, the Rogue fought like a fury, and but for your timely aid I'de been in some danger!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: But Galliard, thou wert telling me thy adventure with Silvianetta! there may be comfort in't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: So, now I shall hear with what concern he speaks of me.-

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Oh damn her, damn her!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: The very'st jilt that ever learnt the Art.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Death the whore took me, for some Amorous English Elder Brother! and was for Matrimony in the devils name! thought me a loving fool, that nere had seen so glorious a sight before! and wou'd at any rate enjoy!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! I am amaz'd! How much he differs from the thing he was, but a few minutes since.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And to advance her price, set up for Quality! may swore she was a Maid! and that she did but Act the Curtizan!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Which then he seem'd to give a credit too,—oh the forsworn dissembler.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: But when I came to the matter then in debate, she was for Honourable Love forsooth, and wou'd not yield no marry wou'd she, not under a Licence from the Parson of the Parish.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Who was it prethee, 'twere a good deed to be so reveng'd on her!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
Pox on her no, I'me sure she's a damn'd gipsie, for at the same
time she had her Lovers in reserve, lay hid in her Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: 'Twas that he took unkindly.
And makes me guilty of that rude Address!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Another Lover had she!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes, our Coxcomb Knight Buffoon, laid by for a rellishing bit, in case I prov'd not season'd to her minde.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Hah! he knew him then!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: But damn her, she passes with the Night, the day will bring new Objects.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Oh I do not doubt it Frank!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: False and inconstant! Oh I shall rave Siilvio.—
sp.stage: Enter Cornelia! in Mans Cloathes with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Here be the Cavaliers! give me kinde Heaven but hold of him, and if I keep him not, I here renounce my charms of wit and Beauty?—Signiors, is there a Cavalier amongst ye call'd Fillamour.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: I own that name; what wou'd you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Only deliver this Signior.
sp.stage: [Fill. goes aside opens his Lanthorn and reads, Jul. and Gall talk aside.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: [Reads.] I'le only tell you I am Brother to that Marcella whom you have injur'd; to oblige you to meet me an hour hence, in the Piazo Despagnia! I need not say with your sword in your hand, since you will there meet,—Julio Sebastiano, Murisim:—hah! her Brother sure—return'd from Travel, [Aside.—Signior—I will not fail to answer it as he desires, [to Cornelia. I'le take this opportunity to steal off undiscover'd, [Aside going out.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So I've done my sisters business, now for my own.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: But my good friend, pray what adventure have you been on to Night.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Faith Sir, 'twas like to have prov'd a pleasant one, I came just now from the Silvianetta,—the fair young Curtizan.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hah! what said the man—came from me!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How Sir, you with Silvianetta! when?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now, all the dear live long Night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A pox take him, who can this be?—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: This Night! this Night! that is not yet departed!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This very happy Night:—I told you I saw a lovely woman at St. Peters Church.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: You did so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I told you too I follow'd her home, but cou'd learn neither her Name nor quality, but my Page getting ino the acquaintance of one of hers, brought me news of both: her Name Silvianetta, her quality a Curtizan!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I at Church yesterday! Now hang me if I had any such devout thoughts about me, whe what a damn'd scandalous Rascall this.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Fill'd with hopes of success, at Night I made her a visit, and under her window had a skirmish with some Rival, who was then serinading her:

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Was't he that fought us then,— [Aside]—but it seems you were not mistaken in the house,—on with your story pray—death I grow jealous now,— [Aside] you came at Night you said?—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, and was receiv'd at the door, by the kind Silvianetta, who softly whisper'd me, come to my bosome and be safe for ever! and doubtless took me for some happier man.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Confusion on him, 'twas my very language!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then led me by dark, into her Chamber!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh this damn'd lying Rascall! I do this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But oh the things, the dear obliging things, the kinde the fair young charmer said and did.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To thee!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Did Silvianetta do this, Silvianetta the Curtizan.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That passes Sir for such, but is indeed of quality.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This stranger is the devil! how shou'd he know that secret else.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: She told me too 'twas for my sake alone, whom from the first minute she saw, she Lov'd! she had assum'd that Name and that disguise, the sooner to invite me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis plain, the things I utter'd!—oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Curse on the publique jilt, the very flattery she wou'd have past on me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pox take him, I must draw on him, I cannot hold!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Was ever such a whore.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh that I knew this man, whom by mistake! [Aside, I lavisht all the secrets of my soul too!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I prest for something more then dear expressions,
And found her yield apace,
But sighing told me, of a fatall Contract,
She was oblig'd to make to one she never saw,
And yet if I wou'd vow to Marry her, when she cou'd prove to
Merrit it, she wou'd deny me nothing.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Twas I, by Heaven that heedless fool was I.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Which I with Lovers eager joy perform'd,
And on my knees utter'd the hasty words,
Which she repeated ore and gave me back!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So, he has swallow'd with a vengeance the very bait she had prepar'd for me, or anybody that wou'd bite.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But ere I cou'd receive the dear reward of all my vows,
I was drawn upon, by a man that lay hid in her Chamber:
Whether by chance or design I know not, who fought me out,
And was the same you found me engag'd with.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A pleasant Rascall this, as ere the devil taught his lesson too.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So, my comfort is she has jilted him too most damnably.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Slife I have anger enough to make me valiant, why shou'd I not make use on't, and beat this lying Villain whilst the sit holds.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And you design to keep these vows, though you're contracted to another woman?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I neither thought of breaking those, or keeping these, My soul was all imploy'd another way.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: —It shall be so,—Silvio—I've thought upon a way that must redeem all,—hark and observe me.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But I'me impatient to pursue my adventure, Which I must endeavour to do, before the light discover the mistake;—Farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Go and be ruin'd quite, she has the knack of doing it.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: I'le warrant ye Madam for my part.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: —I have a damn'd hankering after this woman, why cou'd not I have put the cheat on her, as Julio has, I stand as little on my word as he! a good round Oath or two had done the business,—but a pox on't I lov'd too well to be so wise.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Conlicentia Signior! Is your name Galliard?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I am the man sweet-heart,—let me behold thee—hah—Sans Cour's! Page.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: A dews of his Lanthorn, what shall I say now? [Aside.—Softly Signior, I am that Page whose chiefest business is to attend my Lords Mistriss Sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: His Mistress: whose Mistress, what Mistress; s'life how that little word has nettled me!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Upon my life the woman that he boasted of. [Aside hugging himself.—a fair young Amorous—Noble—Wanton a—And she wou'd speak with me my lovely boy?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You have prevented the commands I had! but should my Lord know of it;—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Thou wert undone! I understand thee—
And will be as secret as a Confessor—
As lonely shades, or everlasting Night—come lead the way.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Where I will follow thee, though to the bed of her thou'rt going too, and even prevent thy very business there.—
sp.stage: Enter Laura as before in a Night-gown. Scone, A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Now for a power that never yet was known
To charm this stranger quickly into love,
Assist my eyes thou God of kinde desires;
Inspire my language with a moving force
That may at once gain and secure the Victory.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Madam your Lovers here: your time's but short, consider too Count Julio may arrive!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Let him arrive! having secur'd my self of what I love,
I'le leave him to complain his unknown losse
To carelesse winds as pittyless as I: Sabina see the Rooms
Be fill'd with lights! whilst I prepare my self to entertain him.
Darkness shall ne're deceive me more—
sp.stage: [Enter to Sil. Gall. gazing •… about him Cor. peeping at the door.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: All's wonderous rich,—Gay as the Court of love, But still and silent as the shades of death;—Hah—Musick! and Excellent! [Soft Musick whilst they speak, Poxon't—but where's the woman—! need no preparation.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No you are always provided for such incounters and can fall too Sans Ceremony,—but I may spoil you stomack.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: A voice too, by Heaven and 'tis a sweet one:
Grant she be young and I'le excuse the rest.
Yet vie for pleasure with the happyest Roman!
sp.stage:
[The Song as by Laura, after which soft Musick till she enters.
The SONG By a Person of Quality.
FArewell the World and mortal cares
The ravisht Strephon cry'd,
As full of joy and tender tears
He lay by
•… hillis side:
Let others toyl for wealth and fame,
Whilst not one thought of mine,
At any other bliss shall aim,
But those dear arms, but those dear arms of thine.
Still let me gaze on thy bright eyes,
And hear thy charming tongue,
I nothing askt' increase my joys
But thus to feel'em long;
In close embraces let us lye,
And spend our lives to come,
Then let us both together dye
And be each others, be each others Tomb.
sp.l: —Death I am fir'd already with her voice.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So, I am like to thrive,—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What mean these lights in every room, as if to make the day without the Sun: and quite destroy my hopes!—hah Galliard here!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A man! grant it some Lover, or some Husband Heaven!
Or any thing that will but spoil the sport,
