The Lady! oh blast her! how fair she is.
sp.stage: [Enter Laura with her Lute drest in a careless rich dress, follow'd by Sabina to whom she gives her Lute.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hah! 'tis the same woman!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A stranger here! what Art can help me now.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: By all my joys a lovely woman 'tis,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Help me deceipt, dissembling, all that's woman—
sp.stage: [She starts and gazes on Gall. pulling Silvio

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sure I shou'd know that face.—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah look my Silvio! is't not he!—it is!
That smile, that Air, that meen, that Bow is his!
'Tis he by all my hopes, by all my wishes!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: He, yes yes, I am a He, I thank my stars
And never blest'em half so much for being so,
As for the dear variety of woman!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Curse on her charms shee'l make him love in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: It is my Brother! and report was false!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How her Brother! Gad I'me sorry we're so neer akin with all My soul; for I am damnably pleas'd with her!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah why do ye shun my Arms—or are ye Ayr!
And not to be inclos'd in human twines—
Perhaps you are the Ghost of that dead Lord!
That comes to whisper vengance to my soul.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Shart! a Ghost! this is an odd preparative to 'love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis Laura! my Brother Julio's Mistress, and Sister to Octavio!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Death, Madam, do not scare away my love, with tales of Ghosts, and fancies of the dead, I'le give ye proofs I'me living loving man, as errant an Amorous a Mortall as heart can wish—I hope she will not jilt me too.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So! he's at his common proof for all Arguments If she shou'd take him at his word now, and she'l be sure to do't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Amiable stranger pardon the mistake!
And charge it on my passion for a Brother!
Devotion was not more retir'd then I,
Vestals, or widow'd Matrons when they weep,
Till by a fatall chance I saw in you;
The dear resemblance of a Murther'd Brother!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What the devil can she mean by this.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I durst not trust my eyes, yet still I gaz'd,
And that encreas'd my faith you were my Brother,
But since they err'd, and he indeed is dead,
Oh give me leave to pay you all that love,
That tenderness and passion that was his!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So, I knew she wou'd bring matters about some way or other, oh mischief mischief help me! 'slife I can be wicked enough when I have no use on't, and now I have, I'me as harmless as a fool.
sp.stage: [As Gall. is earnestly talking to Lau. Julio pulls him by the sleeve.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Oh save me! save me from the Murderer!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A Murderer where!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I faint, I dye with horror of the sight.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Hah—my friend a Murderer! sure you mistake him Madam, he saw not Rome till yesterday,—an honest youth Madam and one that knows his distance upon occasion!—'slife how cam'st thou here—prethee begone and leave us!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why do you know this Lady Sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Know her!—a—ay ay—man—and all her Relations, she's of quality,—withdraw withdraw—Madam—a—he is my friend and shall be civil.—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I have an easie faith for all you say,—but yet however innocent he be or dear to you, I beg he woul'd depart—he is so like my brothers Murtherer, that one look more wou'd kill me—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A Murtherer! charge me with cowardise, with Rapes or Treasons—Gods a Murtherer!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A devil on her! she has rob'd the sex of all their arts of cunning.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Pox on't thou'rt rude! go, in good manners go—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I do conjure ye torture me no more,
If you wou'd have me think you're not that Murtherer.
Be gone—and leave your Friend to calm my heart
Into some kinder thoughts!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Ay, ay, prithee go! I'le be sure to do thy business for thee;

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you will not fail to do a friendly part no doubt—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis but in vain to stay—I see she did mistake her man last Night, and 'twas to chance I am in debt for that good fortune!—I will retire to show my obedience Madam!
sp.stage: [Ex. Jul. Gall. going to the door with him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: He's gone and left me Mistress of my wish!
Descend ye little winged Gods of Love,
Descend and hover round our bower of blisse,
Play all in various forms about the youth;
And empty all our quivers at his heart:
sp.stage: [Gall. returns, she takes him by the hand.
sp.l: —Advance thou dearer to my soul then kindred,
Thou more then Friend or Brother,
Let meaner Souls born base conceal the God!
Love owns his Monarchy within my heart,
So Kings that daign to visit humble roofs:
Enter disguis'd, but in a Noble Palace,
Own their great Power, and show themselves in glory.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: I am all transport with this sudain bliss,
And want some kinde allay to sit my Soul for recompence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my forward friend you shall have an allay, if all my Art can do't, to damp thee even to disappointment.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: My Souls all wonder now, let us retire,
And gaze till I have softend it to Love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: More interruption!—hah.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My Master the young Count Julio.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Julio!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What of him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Being just now arriv'd at Rome!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heavens! arriv'd!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sent me to beg the Honour of waiting on you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sure stranger you mistake!—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: If Madam you are Laura Lucretia!—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Laura Lucretia! by Heaven the very woman he's to marry.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: This wou'd surprise a Virgin less resolv'd,
But what have I to do with ought but Love!
—And can your Lord imagine this an hour,
To make a ceremonious visit in!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Ridles by Love! or is't some trick again.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, where vows are past, the want of ceremony may be pardon'd!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I do not use to have my will disputed,
Begone and let him know I'le be obey'd!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Slife she'l out-wit me yet,—
Madam I see this niceness is not general,
—You can except some Lovers.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: My pert young confident depart, and let your Master know he'l finde a better welcome from the fair vain Curtizan, la Silvianetta! where he has past the Night and given his vows.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Dearly devis'd and I must take the hint.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He knows me sure, and says all this to plague me. [Aside. My Lord, my Master with a Curtizan! he's but just now ariv'd.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A pretty focward sawcy lying boy this! and may do well in time,—Madam believe him not, I saw his Master yesterday,—converst with him,—I know him he's my friend!—'twas he that parted hence but now,—he told me all his passion for a Curtizan, scarce half an hour since.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I do not doubt it, oh how I love him for this seasonable lye,
—And can you think I'le see a perjur'd man,
Who gives my intrest in him to another,
—Do I not help ye out most Artfully.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I see they are resolv'd to out face me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Nay vow'd to marry her!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heavens to marry her!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: To be conquer'd at my own weapon too,—lying 'tis a hard case!—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Go boy you may be gone, you have your Answer childe, And may depart—come Madam let us leave him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Gone! no help, death I'le quarrel with him,—nay fight him,—Damn him,—rather then loose him thus,—stay Signior, [Pulls him.—You call me boy,—but you may finde your self mistaken Sir,—And know—I've that about me may convince ye, [Showing his sword.—'Thas done some Execution!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Prethee on whom or what? small Village curs! The barking of a Mastive wou'd unman thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Hold—follow me from the refuge of her Arms!
As thou'rt a man, I do conjure thee do't:
—'hope he will, I'le venture beating for't.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes, my brisk—little Rascal—I will—a—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: By all that's good you shall not stir from hence, ho who waits there, Antonio, Silvio, Gaspero, [Enter all]—take that firce youth and bear him from my sight.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You shall not need, 'slife these rough Rogues will be too hard for me,—'ve one prevention left,—farewell, Maist thou supply her with as feable Art, As I shou'd do, were I to play thy part.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: He's gone! Now lets redeem our blessed minutes lost. [Goin Scene changes to the Street.— Piazo Despagnia!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now by this breaking daylight I cou'd rave, I knew she mistook me last Night which made me so eager to improve my luckey minutes,—fure Galliard is not the man, I long to know the mistery,—hah—who's here—Fillamour.
sp.stage: [Enter Fillamour met by Marcella in Mans Clothes, they pass by each other—cock and justle.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I take it—you are he I look for Sir!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: My Name is Fillamour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mine,—Julio Sebastiano Murisini.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hah, my Name by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: I doubt it not, since in that Lovely face,
I see the charming Image of Marcella!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hah.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You might, ere Travel rufled me to man,
—I shou'd return thy praise whilst I survey thee,
But that I came not here for Complement,—draw.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Why cause thou'rt like Marcella?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That were sufficient reason for thy hate,
But mine's because thou hast betray'd her basely;
—She told me all the story of her Love,
How well you meant, how honestly you swore,
And with a thousand tears imploy'd my Aid:
To break the contract she was forc't to make,
T'Octavio, and give her to your Arms.
I did, and brought you word of our design,
—I need not tell ye what returns you made;
Let it suffice my Sister was neglected,
Neglected for a Curtizan,—a whore!
I watcht and saw each circumstance of falshood,

sp.speaker: Jul,
sp.p: Damnation! what means this?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: I scorn to save my life by lyes or flatterys,
But credit me, the Visit that I made,
I durst have sworn had been to my Marcella!
Her Face, her Eyes, her Beauty was the same,
Only the business of her Language differ'd,
And undeceiv'd my hope.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In vain thou think'st to flatter me to faith,—
When thou'dst my Sisters Letter in thy hand, which ended that dispute
Even then I saw with what regret you read it:
What care you took to disobey it too,—
The shivering Maid, half dead with fears and terrors of the Night,
In vain expected a relief from Love or thee,
Draw that I may return her the glad news I have reveng'd her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hold much mistaken youth! 'tis I am Julio, thou Fillamour know'st my Name, knows I ariv'd but yesterday at Rome, and heard the killing news of both my Sisters flights, Marcella and Cornelia,—and thou art some Imposture.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If this now shou'd be true, I were in a fine condition.—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Fled! Marcella fled!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Twas she I told thee yesterday was lost,
But why art thou concern'd,—explain the Mistery!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: I lov'd her more then life! nay even than Heaven!
And dost thou question my concern for her,
Say how! and why! and whether is she fled!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh wou'd I knew, that I might kill her in her Lovers Arms, Or if I found her innocent, restore her to Octavio!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: To Octavio! and is my friendship of so little worth, You cannot think I merrit her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This is some trick between 'em! but I have sworn most solemnly, have sworn by Heaven and my Honour to resign her, and I will do't or dye,—therefore declare quickly, declare where she's, or I will leave thee dead upon the place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So, death or Octavio, a pretty hopefull choice this.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Hold! by Heaven you shall not touch a single hair, thus—will I guard the secret in his bosome.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis plain thoust injur'd me,—and to my Honour I'le sacrifice my friendship, follow me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah Petro, fly fly swist and rescue him.—
sp.stage: [Exiunt Pet. with his sword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh have I found thee, fit for my purpose too. Come hast along with me,—thou must present my Brother Julio instantly, or I am lost, and my projects lost, and my mans lost, and all's lost.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Victoria, Victoria, your Cavaliers and Conqueror! the other wounded in his sword hand, was easily disarm'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then lets retire, if I am seen I'me lost,—Petro stay here for the Cavalier, and conduct him to me to this house;—I must be speedy now.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Remember this is Julio!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I know your design and warrant ye my part:—hah Octavio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Now cowardise that everlasting infamy, dwell ever on my face, that men may point me out that hated Lover, that saw his Mistress false, stood tamely by whilst she repeated vows! nay was so infamous so dully tame, to hear her swear her hatred and aversion, yet still I calmly listend! thongh my sword were ready, and did not cut his throat for't.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: I thought, you'd said you'd fought.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yes, I did rouse at last and wak'd my wrongs,
But like an Ass a patient fool of Honour,
I gave him friendly Notice I wou'd kill him;
And fought like prizers not as angry Rivals.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Why that was hansome,—I love fair play what wou'd you else have done!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Have fall'n upon him like a sudain storm, [Enter Pet. and Fill. quick unexpected in his height of Love:—see—see yonder! or I'me mistaken by this glimering day or that is Fillamour; now entering at her door, 'tis he by my revenge:—what say you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: By th' Mass I think it was he,—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Julio I've caught the wantons in their toyl,
I have 'em fast, thy sister and her Lover.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Eternal shame light on me, if they scape then!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Follow me quick,—whilst we can get admittance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Where—here!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Here,—come all and see her shame and my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And are you not mistaken in the house.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Mistaken! I saw the Ravisher enter just now, thy Uncle saw it too, oh my Excessive joy, come if I lye—say I'me a dog a Villain!
sp.stage: Scene changes to a Chamber, Enter Sir Signal—a little groping.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: There's no finding my way out,—and now does fear make me fancy,—this some Inchanted Castle.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Hah an Inchanted Castle!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Belonging to a monsterous Giant! who having spirited away the King of Tropicipopicans Daughter, keeps her here inclos'd, and that I wandering Knight am by fickle Fortune sent to her deliverance.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How's that! spirited away the King of Tropicipopicans daughter! bless me what unlawfull wickedness is practic'd, in this Romish Heathenish Countreys!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: And yet the devil of any dwarfe Squire or Damzel have I met with yet:—wou'd I were clenlily off a this business,—hah lights as I live! and people coming this way!—bless me from the Giant,—Oh Lord what shall I do.—

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I fear no Giants, having justice on my side, but Reputation makes me tender of my person!—hah—what's this a Curtain: I'le winde my self in this, it may secure me!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: —They're entering, what shall I do—hah—here's a corner! defend me from a Chimney.
sp.stage: [Creeps to the corner of the Window, and feels a space between Tick. legs and the corner, creeps in and stands up just behind Tickletext. Enter Gall. leading Laura! Sab. with lights just after 'em! Jul. Oct. Mur. and Crap.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Just in the happy minute.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I've sworn by every God! by every power divine! to Marry thee! and save thee from the Tyranny of a forc't Contract,—Nay Gad if I loose a fine wench for want of Oaths this bout the devil's in me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What think ye now Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Damnation on her, set my rage at liberty! [Mur. holds him. that I may kill 'em both!

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: I see no cause for that, she may be virtuous yet.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: De ye think as such to pass her off on me,
Or that I'le bear the infamy of your Family,
No I scorn her now, but can revenge my Honour on a Rival!

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Nay then I'le see fair play,—turn and defend thy life.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Whilst I do justice on the Prostitute!—hah—Gall.
Defend me 'tis the woman that I Love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Laura! my sister! persidious shamefull!—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hold! thy sister this? that sister I'me to marry! (wretched.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Is this then Julio! and do all the powers conspire to make me

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: May I be dumb for ever!
sp.stage: [Holds his sword down and looks sadly, Jul. holds Lau. by one hand pleads with Oct. with the other, Enter Fillamour and Pet.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: —Hah Galliard! in danger too!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Fillamour here, how now what's the matter friend.
sp.stage: [they talk whilst Enter Marcella and Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hah new broyls, sure the devil's broke loose to Night!—my Uncle as I live!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Octavio! where shall we fly for safety!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'le ene trust to my Breeches! 'tis too late to retreat!—'slife here be our Cavaliers too, nay then nere fear falling into the Enemies hands!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 , I fled with Marcella! had I been blest with so much Love from her, I wou'd have boasted on't 'ith face of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: La ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: The lovely Maid, I own I have a passion for,
But by the powers above the flame was sacred,
And wou'd no more have past the bounds of Honour,
Or hospitallity! then I wou'd basely Murther! and were she free,
I wou'd from all the World make her for ever mine.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Look ye Sir, a plain case this.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: He tells ye simple truth Sir.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Was it not you, this scarce past Night I fought with here, in the house by dark! just when you had exchanged your vows with her!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Heavens! was it he •… ?

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: This minute was the first I ever entred here!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Twas I Sir, was that interrupted Lover,—and this the Lady!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And must •… yield at last.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Wonders and Ridles!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And was this the Silvianetta Sir, you told the story of!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The same whom inclination, friends and destiny, Conspire to make me blest with.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: So many disappointments in one Night, wou'd make a man turn honest in spight of Nature!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Some comfort yet, that I am not the only fool defeated! hah! Galliard.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'me satisfied! [to Fill.] —but what cou'd move you Sir,— [to Gall.] to injure me! one of my Birth and Quality!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Faith Sir I never stand upon ceremony when there's a woman in the case,—nor knew I 'twas your Sister: Or if I had I shou'd alik'd her nere the worse for that, had she been kind.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is my business to account with him,
And I am satisfy'd he has not injur'd me! he is my friend!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: That's frankly said! and uncompel'd I swear she's innocent!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If you're convinc't! I too am satisfy'd!
And give her to you whilst that faith continues!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And must I, must I force my heart to yield!
And yet his generous confidence Obliges me!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And here I vow! by all the sacred Powers, [Kneels.] that punish perjury, never to set my heart on saithless woman!—Never to Love nor Marry! [Rises.] Travel shall be my business,—thou my Heir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: So, poor soal, I warrant he has been deseated too!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marcella Sir will take ye at your word!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Who owns with blushes truths shou'd beconceal'd, but to prevent more mischief,—that I was yours Sir was against my will, [to Oct. my soul was Fillamours ere you claim d a right in me; though I nere saw or held discourse with him, but at an awfull distance,—nor knew he of my flight.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I do believe, and give thee back my claim, I scorn the brutal part of Love! the noblest body where the heart is wanting.
sp.stage: [They all talk aside, Cornelia comes up to Galliard!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Whe how now Cavalier! how like a discarded favorite do you look now, who whilst your Authority lasted laid about ye; domineerd huft and blusterd, as if there had been no end on't, now a man may approach ye without terror!—you see the meats snatcht out of your mouth Sir, the Lady's dispos'd on! who's Friends and Relations you were so well acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Peace boy, I shall be angry else.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Have you never a cast Mistress that will take compassion on you: faith what think you of the little Curtizan now!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: As ill as ere I did! what's that to thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Much more then you're aware on Sir,—and faith to tell you truth I'me no servant to Count Julio! but ene a little michievous instrument she sent hither to prevent your making Love to Dona Laura!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: 'Tis she her self,—how cou'd that beauty hide it self so long from being known! [Aside.]—Malicious little dog in a Manger, that wou'd neither eat, nor suffer the hungry to feed themselves! what spitefull devil cou'd move thee to treat a Lover thus! but I am pretty well reveng'd on ye!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: On me!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: You think I did not know those pretty Eyes! that lovely Mouth I have so often kist in cold imagination

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Softly tormentor!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: In this difguse we parted from Vitterbo! atended only by Petro, and I hil pa! at Rome we took the Title and habit of two Curtizans; both to shelter us from knowledge, and to Oblige Fillamour to visit us, which we beliv'd he wou'd in curiosity, and yesterday it so fell out as we desir'd!

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: How ere my eyes might be impos'd upon, you see my heart was firm to its first object, can you forget and pardon the mistake!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: She shall! and with Octavio's—and my Uncles leave,—thus make your Title good.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: 'Tis vain to strive with destiny!

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: With all my heart,—but where's Cornelia all this while!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Here's the fair stragler Sir.
sp.stage: [Leads her to Mur. he holds his Cane up at her.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Why thou baggage, thou wicked contriver of mischief, what excuse hadst thou for running away, thou hadst no Lover?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Twas therefore Sir I went to finde one! and if I am not mistaken in the mark, 'tis this Cavalier I pitch upon for that use and purpose.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Gad I thank ye for that,—I hope you'l ask my leave first, I'me finely drawn in efaith!—have I been dreaming all this Night, of the possession of a new gotten Mistress, to wake and finde my self nooz'd to a dull wise in the morning.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Thou talkst like a man that never knew the pleasures thou dispisest; faith try it Frank and thou wilt hate thy past loose way of living.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And to encourage a young setter up, I do here promise to be the most Mistriss like wise,—you know Signior I have learnt the trade, though I had not stock to practice, and will be as expensive, Insolent, vain Extravagant, and Inconstant, as if you only had the keeping part, and another the Amorous Asignations, what think ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Faith she pleads well! and ought to cary the cause!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: She speaks Reason! and I'me resolv'd to trust good Nature!—give me thy dear hand.—
sp.stage: [They all joyn to give it him, he kisses it.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: And now you are both speed, pray give me leave to ask ye a civil question! are you sure you have been honest, if you have I know not by what Miracle you have liv'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Oh Sir as for that, I had a small stock of cash, in the hands of a cuple of English Bankers, on Sir Signal Buffoon.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Sir Signal Buffoon! what a pox does he mean me trow.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: —And one Mr. Tickletext!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How was that,—certo my Name!
sp.stage: [Peeps out and both see each other their faces, being close together one at one side the Curtain, and tother at tother.

sp.speaker: Gall. and Fill.
sp.p: Ha ha ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: And have I caught you efaith Mr. Governor! Nay nere put in your head for the matter, here's none but friends mun!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How now what have we here!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Speak of the devil and he appears!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I am nndone!—but good Sir Signal do not cry whore first! as the old proverb says!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: And good Mr. Governor, as another old proverb says, do not let the kettle call the Pot black-ars!—

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: How came you hither Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Whe! faith Sir divining of a wedding or two forward, I brought Mr. Chaplain to give you a cast of his Office, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: What without Book Mr. Tickletext.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How now! sure you mistake, these are two Lovers of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: How Sir your Lovers! we are none of those Sir, we are Englishmen!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: You mistake Sir Signal, this is Silvianetta!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig. and Tick.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Here's another spark of your acquaintance,—do you know him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How Barberacho! nay then all will out.—

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes, and your fencing and Civility-Master.

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: Ay,—whe what was it you that pickt our pocket's then,—and cheated us!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Most damnably,—but since 'twas for the supply of two fair Ladys, all shall be restor'd again.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Some comfort that.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.p: Come lets in and forgive all, 'twas but one Nights Intrigue, in which all were a little faulty!

sp.speaker: Sir Sig.
sp.p: And Governor, pray let me have no more dominering and Usurpation! But, as we have hitherto been honest Brothers in iniquity, so let's wink hereafter at each others frailties! Since Love and women easily betray man, From the grave Gown-man to the busy Lay-man.

div.head: The EPILOGUE,
div.l: SO hard the Times are, and so thin the Town,
Though but one Playhouse, that must too lie down;
And when we fail what will the Poets do?
They live by us as we are kept by you:
When we disband, they no more Plays will write,
But make Lampoons, and Libell ye in spight;
Discover each false heart that lies within,
Nor Man nor Woman shall in private sin;
The precise whoring Husbands haunts betray,
Which the demurer Lady to repay,
In his own coin does the just debt defray.
The brisk young Beauty linkt to Lands and Age,
Shuns the dull property, and strokes the youthfull Page;
And if the stripling apprehend not soon,
Turns him aside and takes the brawny Groom,
Whilst the kinde man so true a Husband proves,
To think all's well done by the thing he loves;
Knows he's a Cuckold, yet content to bear
What 'ere Heaven sends, or horns or lusty heir;
Fops of all sorts he draws more artfully,
Then ever on the Stage did Nokes or Leigh:
And Heaven be prais'd when these are scarce, each Brother
O'th pen, contrive to set on one another:
These are the effects of angry Poets rage,
Driven from their Winter-Quarters on the Stage,
And when we go, our Women vanish too,
What will the well-fledg'd keeping Gallant do?
And where but here can he expect to finde,
A gay young Dam'sell manag'd to his minde,
Who ruines him and yet seems wondrous kinde.
One insolent and false, and what is worse,
Governs his heart and manages his purse;
Makes him whate're she'd have him to believe,
Spends his Estate, then learns him how to live;
I hope these weighty considerations will
Move ye to keep us all together still;
To treat us equal to our great desert,
And pay your Tributes with a franker heart,
If not, th'aforesaid Ills will come, and we must part.
